title: Oral Presentation Skills — Planning Your Talk
description: Students learn the fundamentals of oral presentation by planning a short talk on a topic they know well. They explore how great speakers organize their thoughts, use eye contact and voice projection, and engage their audience from the very first sentence.
instructions:
1. Ask: What makes a great speaker? Brainstorm qualities together.
2. Introduce the three parts of a presentation: opening hook, body, closing.
3. Discuss the opening hook: a question, a surprising fact, or a short story.
4. Explain the body: 3 main points, each with a supporting detail or example.
5. Discuss the closing: summarize, give a final thought, thank the audience.
6. Model a 2-minute talk on a familiar topic (e.g., 'Why I Love Cooking').
7. Students choose their own topic from a list or their own interest.
8. Students create a planning sheet with hook, 3 points, and closing.
9. Practice reading through the plan quietly to themselves.
10. Pair up and share topics — partners give encouraging feedback.

slides.heading: Oral Presentation Skills
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our big adventure today! It tells us we're going to learn how to be super speakers by planning out what we want to say. Think of it like getting ready for a play – you need to know your lines and how you'll act them out!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a planning sheet template with sections for: Opening Hook, Main Point 1 with detail, Main Point 2 with detail, Main Point 3 with detail, and Closing. Have a list of topic suggestions ready (My Favorite Animal, A Place I Love, How to Make Something, A Book I Recommend, Something I Am Good At). Set up a space where students can practice speaking.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll use to plan our talks. We have a special paper called a planning sheet to write our ideas on, a pencil for writing, some cards to help us remember our points, a list of fun topic ideas, and a timer to keep us on track. You'll need to gather these up so we can get started!

slides.text: Think about the best speakers you have heard — teachers, storytellers, people in videos. What makes them great? They LOOK at their audience. They speak CLEARLY and LOUDLY enough to be heard. They are ORGANIZED — you can follow what they are saying. And they seem EXCITED about their topic. Today you will learn to do all of these things!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important clue about what makes someone a great speaker! Think about people you really like listening to – they don't just talk, they really connect with you. They look at you, speak clearly, and seem excited, which makes you want to listen too. We're going to learn how to do all that today!

slides.text: Every great presentation has three parts: an OPENING HOOK that grabs attention, a BODY with your main points, and a CLOSING that wraps it up. The hook is the most important — it makes people WANT to listen. You can start with a question ('Have you ever wondered...?'), a surprising fact, or a tiny story. NEVER start with 'Um, my presentation is about...'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, imagine you're telling a story. You need a way to get your listener excited right away, right? That's the "opening hook"! This slide tells us we can start with a fun question, a super surprising fact, or a quick little story to make everyone lean in and listen. It's way better than just saying "Here's my talk."

slides.text: The body of your talk has THREE main points. Why three? Because three is easy to remember — for you AND your audience. Each point needs a detail or example to make it interesting. For example, if your topic is 'Why Dogs Are Great Pets,' your three points might be: they are loyal, they keep you active, and they make you happy. Each point gets a story or fact.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains the middle part of your talk, called the "body." It's like the main adventure in your story! You'll pick three main things you want to share, and for each of those things, you'll add a little detail or example to make it super interesting for your audience. Think of it like having three cool stops on a treasure hunt!

slides.text: Your closing should summarize your three points in one sentence, give a final thought or call to action, and end with 'Thank you.' A strong ending is just as important as a strong beginning. Watch me give a sample talk so you can see all the parts in action. [Teacher models a 2-minute presentation.]
slides.mascot_explanation: We're almost done planning! This slide shows us how to finish strong. Your closing is like the grand finale – you'll quickly remind everyone of your three main points, share one last cool thought, and then thank everyone for listening. A good ending helps people remember how awesome your talk was, just like a great movie ending!

slides.prompt:
Choose a topic you know well and care about. Fill out your planning sheet:
1. Write an opening hook (question, fact, or story)
2. Write 3 main points with a detail for each
3. Write a closing sentence and final thought
4. Transfer your key words to index cards (one card per point)
5. Practice reading through your plan quietly
6. Share your topic and hook with a partner — does it grab their attention?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the star! Your job is to pick a topic you love, like your favorite animal or a fun hobby, and fill out your planning sheet. First, write a super exciting hook, then list your three main points with details, and finally, write your closing. After that, you'll write down the most important words on your index cards and practice saying them quietly.

slides.text: You now have a plan for a real presentation! The secret of great speakers is not natural talent — it is PREPARATION. By organizing your thoughts into a hook, three points, and a closing, you have a roadmap that will keep you on track. Next time we will practice delivering your talk with confidence.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the three parts of a presentation? Can they write an engaging opening hook? Can they organize three main points with supporting details? Do they understand the purpose of a strong closing?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you've done! You've created a plan for your very own presentation, just like real speakers do. You figured out how to grab attention with a hook, share your ideas with three main points, and finish with a great closing. All this planning is the secret ingredient to sounding confident and amazing when you speak next time!

parent_notes: Public speaking is consistently rated as one of the most feared activities, even for adults. By teaching presentation skills in elementary school within a supportive environment, we build confidence that lasts a lifetime. The Montessori approach emphasizes that children have something valuable to share — their knowledge, passions, and experiences. The planning sheet provides structure without being rigid. Let your child choose a topic they genuinely care about; authentic enthusiasm is the best antidote to nervousness. Practice at home should be encouraging — focus on what they do well before suggesting improvements. The three-point structure is used by professional speakers worldwide because it works.

title: Fractions Review — Naming and Identifying Fractions
description: Students review fraction concepts by naming fractions from visual models, identifying fractions on number lines, and matching fraction names to their symbolic representations. This lesson consolidates understanding of numerators and denominators using concrete materials.
instructions:
1. Review: What is a fraction? A part of a whole divided into equal pieces.
2. Display fraction circles — identify halves, thirds, fourths, sixths, eighths.
3. Review vocabulary: numerator (parts we have), denominator (total equal parts).
4. Show fractions on number lines — connect to fraction circles.
5. Practice naming fractions from pictures: 'What fraction is shaded?'
6. Reverse: draw fractions from names — 'Show me 3/4.'
7. Introduce equivalent fractions visually: 2/4 = 1/2 — they cover the same amount.
8. Students complete a fraction identification worksheet.
9. Fraction card matching game: match pictures to fraction names.
10. Discuss: Where do we see fractions in everyday life?

slides.heading: Fractions Review
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our book for today! It tells us we're going to be reviewing something super important in math called fractions, and we'll learn how to say their names and find them. It's like learning the secret code for parts of things!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out fraction circles with all denominations visible (halves through tenths). Prepare a large number line from 0 to 1 marked with common fractions. Print a worksheet with shapes partially shaded for fraction identification. Create matching cards with fraction pictures on one set and fraction names on another.
slides.mascot_explanation: Whoa, look at all these cool math tools! We've got these round fraction circles or bar shapes that are already cut into equal pieces, which will help us see fractions. Then there's a long line with numbers on it, like a ruler for fractions, and a paper with pictures to fill in, plus some cards for a game. We'll need our math notebook and some colorful pencils too, so make sure you have all those things ready!

slides.text: A fraction tells us about PARTS of a WHOLE. When we cut something into EQUAL pieces and take some of those pieces, we have a fraction. The DENOMINATOR (bottom number) tells how many equal pieces the whole is divided into. The NUMERATOR (top number) tells how many pieces we are talking about. Let us review with our fraction circles.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is the super important part: what a fraction *is*. Think about sharing a pizza – if you cut it into equal slices, each slice is a fraction of the whole pizza! The bottom number, the denominator, tells us how many total equal slices there are, and the top number, the numerator, tells us how many slices we're looking at or have.

slides.text: Hold up the fraction circle for 1/2. The whole circle is cut into 2 equal pieces, and we are looking at 1 of them. Now 1/3: the circle is cut into 3 equal pieces, we have 1. Now 3/4: the circle is cut into 4 equal pieces, we have 3. Notice: as the denominator gets BIGGER, each piece gets SMALLER. 1/8 is smaller than 1/4!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's play with these fraction circles! See how the one for 1/2 is cut into two big pieces? When we look at 1/3, it's cut into three smaller pieces, and 1/8 is cut into even tinier pieces! It's like magic: the more pieces we cut the whole into, the smaller each individual piece becomes.

slides.text: Fractions also live on the NUMBER LINE. Zero is on the left, 1 (one whole) is on the right. 1/2 is exactly in the middle. 1/4 is halfway between 0 and 1/2. 3/4 is halfway between 1/2 and 1. Place your fraction pieces along the number line to see how they match up.
slides.mascot_explanation: Fractions aren't just for circles; they live on a number line too! Imagine this line is a path from zero to one whole thing. The 1/2 mark is exactly in the middle, and we can see how other fractions, like 1/4, fit right in between the numbers. You can even use your fraction pieces to see how they line up perfectly on the number line!

slides.text: Something amazing: DIFFERENT fractions can name the SAME amount! Look: 1/2 of the circle and 2/4 of the circle cover exactly the same space. And 2/4 equals 3/6 equals 4/8 — they all mean the same thing! These are called EQUIVALENT FRACTIONS. You can check by laying one fraction piece on top of another.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for a mind-blowing trick: sometimes different fractions can actually mean the *exact same amount*! Look at this – if you have 1/2 of a circle, and then you have 2/4 of another circle, they cover the same space! These are called equivalent fractions, and they're like secret twins that look different but are really the same.

slides.prompt:
Complete the fraction review:
1. Fraction Worksheet: Name the fraction shown in each picture (12 problems)
2. Draw these fractions: 2/3, 5/8, 1/4, 3/6, 7/10
3. Matching Game: Match each fraction picture card to its name card
4. Find 3 pairs of equivalent fractions using your fraction circles
5. In your notebook, list 5 places you see fractions in everyday life (cooking, pizza, time, money, measuring)
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to put your fraction detective skills to work! First, you'll look at some pictures on the worksheet and write down what fraction is shaded in. Then, you'll get to draw some fractions yourself, like showing what 2/3 looks like. After that, we'll play a fun matching game with the cards, and you’ll find some equivalent fractions using your circle pieces, and finally, think about where you see fractions in your own life!

slides.text: Fractions are everywhere — in cooking (1/2 cup), in time (quarter hour), in music (half note), and in sharing (1/3 of the cookies). Understanding fractions means understanding how wholes can be divided fairly and precisely. You have reviewed naming, identifying, and comparing fractions — these skills will serve you in every area of math and life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly name fractions from visual models? Can they draw fractions from symbolic notation? Do they understand the relationship between numerator and denominator? Can they identify at least two pairs of equivalent fractions?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You've become a fraction expert today, understanding how to name them, draw them, and even finding those cool equivalent fractions. Remember how we saw fractions everywhere, like in sharing pizza or measuring ingredients for baking? That’s why learning fractions is so awesome – it helps us understand the world around us better!

parent_notes: Fraction understanding is one of the most critical mathematical milestones in elementary school, and research consistently shows it predicts later success in algebra. The Montessori fraction circles make abstract concepts concrete — children can physically see that 2/4 is the same as 1/2 by overlaying the pieces. Common misconceptions to watch for: thinking that a larger denominator means a larger fraction (1/8 is NOT bigger than 1/4 even though 8 is bigger than 4), and confusing numerator and denominator. Connect fractions to real life constantly: share a snack in thirds, measure ingredients in fourths, discuss how much of a book is finished. The matching game provides repetition without tedium.

title: American Revolution — The Treaty of Paris and War's End
description: Students learn how the American Revolution concluded with the British surrender at Yorktown and the Treaty of Paris in 1783. They explore what the treaty meant for the new nation, what challenges lay ahead, and how thirteen colonies became the United States of America.
instructions:
1. Review the Battle of Yorktown from last week — the final major battle.
2. Describe the British surrender: Cornwallis sends his sword, the army lays down arms.
3. Explain that fighting ended but the war was not officially over.
4. Introduce the Treaty of Paris (1783): Britain officially recognized American independence.
5. Key terms: Britain gave up all land east of the Mississippi, fishing rights, prisoner release.
6. Discuss: What did it FEEL like for Americans? Joy, relief, uncertainty.
7. The challenges ahead: no constitution yet, war debts, governing 13 different states.
8. Students create a 'Before and After' comparison chart (Colonies vs. New Nation).
9. Write a journal entry as a citizen hearing news of peace.
10. Add the Treaty of Paris to the classroom timeline.
materials_needed: Map of the new United States (1783 boundaries)
Images of the Treaty of Paris signing

slides.heading: The Revolution Ends
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our book about the end of the American Revolution! It tells us we're going to learn about how the war finished and a really important paper called the Treaty of Paris that was signed in 1783. Think of it as the "The End" title card for the whole exciting story of fighting for freedom.

items: Images of Treaty of Paris signing
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a map showing the new US boundaries from the Atlantic to the Mississippi River. Have images of the British surrender at Yorktown and the Treaty of Paris signing. Create a comparison chart with two columns: 'Before (Colonies)' and 'After (New Nation)' with rows for Government, Leader, Laws, Taxes, and Land.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our learning adventure today! We've got a map to see what the United States looked like right after the war, a timeline to put things in order, some pictures of important moments, a special journal and pencil for you to write in, and a chart to fill out. Make sure you have a grown-up help you gather all these items so we're ready to go!

slides.text: After the Battle of Yorktown in October 1781, General Cornwallis knew the war was lost. He surrendered his entire army — over 7,000 British soldiers laid down their weapons while a band played. When King George III heard the news in London, he reportedly said, 'Oh God, it is all over.' But it took TWO MORE YEARS before the war was officially ended by a treaty.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we find out how the fighting actually stopped! Remember how the Americans won a big battle at Yorktown? Well, after that, the British general knew they couldn't win anymore, so he gave up his whole army. Imagine thousands of soldiers putting down their weapons while music played – it was a huge moment, but it still took a couple more years for everything to be officially settled with a peace treaty.

slides.text: In September 1783, American and British representatives met in Paris, France, to sign a peace treaty. Benjamin Franklin, John Adams, and John Jay represented America. The TREATY OF PARIS had several key terms: Britain recognized the United States as an independent nation, the US boundary extended west to the Mississippi River, Americans could fish in Canadian waters, and all prisoners of war would be released.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to the super important Treaty of Paris! This is like the official "We agree to be friends again" paper, but for countries. In 1783, people from America and Britain met in Paris and signed this treaty. It said that Britain finally agreed the United States was its own country, and it also decided where the new country would stretch to, that Americans could fish by Canada, and that everyone who was captured would be set free.

slides.text: Think about what this moment meant. For eight long years, colonists had fought, suffered, and sacrificed. Many had lost homes, businesses, and loved ones. Now they were FREE — but freedom brought new questions. Who would lead? What kind of government would they create? How would 13 different states work together? The war was over, but the work of building a nation was just beginning.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide asks us to think about how people felt when they heard the war was finally over. Imagine fighting for something really important for eight whole years – people were tired, they had lost things, and maybe even people they loved. So, even though they were super happy and excited to be free, they probably also wondered, "What happens now?" It was a mix of joy and a little bit of worry about the future.

slides.text: Let us compare BEFORE and AFTER. Before: 13 colonies ruled by a king, laws made in Parliament, taxes they could not vote on. After: 13 states in a new nation, no king, they would make their own laws and decide their own taxes. But they also had huge war debts, a weak government, and no constitution yet. They had won their freedom — now they had to figure out how to USE it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we're going to compare what things were like *before* the war ended and what they were like *after*. Before, the 13 places were called colonies and were ruled by a king far away. After, they were a new nation where they could make their *own* rules and choose their *own* leaders! But it wasn't all easy – they had lots of money to pay back from the war and no rulebook yet, called a constitution.

slides.prompt:
Two activities:
1. Complete the Before and After chart comparing life as colonies vs. life as a new nation. Include at least 5 differences in areas like government, leaders, laws, taxes, land, and rights.
2. Write a journal entry as a citizen in 1783 hearing the news that the war is officially over. How do you feel? What are you excited about? What worries you about the future? Use at least 8 sentences.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time for some fun activities to show what we've learned! First, you'll fill out that chart comparing the colonies to the new United States, thinking about things like who was in charge and who made the laws. Then, you get to be a history detective and write a journal entry like someone back then, sharing how you'd feel hearing the war was over – what would make you happy, and what might make you a little nervous?

slides.text: The American Revolution changed the world. For the first time, a colony had successfully fought for independence and created a new nation based on the idea that people could govern themselves. The Treaty of Paris made it official, but the real revolution was in the IDEA: that ordinary people have the right to choose their own government. The challenges ahead — writing a constitution, uniting the states, addressing slavery — would test this idea for generations to come.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the significance of the Treaty of Paris? Can they describe at least 3 terms of the treaty? Can they compare colonial life before and after independence? Do they understand that winning the war was just the beginning of building a nation?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we just learned how the American Revolution ended and a whole new country was born! The Treaty of Paris made it official, but the most amazing part is the idea that people can choose their own leaders and make their own rules. Even though there were big challenges ahead, like writing a constitution, the United States started with this powerful idea of freedom and self-government.

parent_notes: This lesson brings closure to the American Revolution unit while opening the door to the next chapter of American history — the Constitutional period. The comparison chart helps children organize their understanding of the enormous changes independence brought. The journal writing exercise develops empathy and historical thinking by asking children to imagine themselves in another time. Be honest about the complexities: not everyone benefited equally from independence. Enslaved people were not freed, Native Americans lost protection treaties with Britain, and Loyalists lost property. These nuances are appropriate for this age group and develop critical thinking. The key takeaway is that the Revolution was about IDEAS — self-governance, liberty, representation — that continue to shape the world today.

title: US Southeast Region — States and Physical Features
description: Students begin their study of the US Southeast region by identifying its states, locating major physical features, and understanding how the warm climate, coastline, and river systems shape the region's character. They explore the Appalachian Mountains, the coastal plains, the Mississippi River delta, and the Gulf Coast.
instructions:
1. Review: Which region did we study last? (Northeast) What made it special?
2. Introduce the Southeast region on the US map — identify the states.
3. Southeast states: Virginia, West Virginia, Kentucky, Tennessee, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas.
4. Major physical features: Appalachian Mountains (western border), Atlantic coastal plain, Gulf Coast.
5. Rivers: Mississippi River, Ohio River, Tennessee River — water highways.
6. Climate: warm and humid, long growing season, hurricanes along coasts.
7. Special features: Everglades (Florida), Outer Banks (NC), Mississippi Delta.
8. Students label Southeast states on a blank map.
9. Add physical features: mountains, rivers, coastline, Everglades.
10. Compare Southeast to Northeast — how are they different?

slides.heading: The US Southeast Region
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the cover of a book about a brand new place in the United States! It tells us we're going to learn all about the US Southeast region, and what makes it special, like its states and cool land shapes.

items: US political map showing state boundaries
Blank Southeast region map for labeling
slides.setup_instructions: Have both a political map (showing state names) and a physical map (showing mountains, rivers, coastlines) available. Prepare blank outline maps of the Southeast region for students to label. Gather images of key landmarks: Appalachian Mountains, Everglades, Mississippi River, Gulf Coast beaches, Outer Banks.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these supplies! We have maps to see where things are, a special map just for our new region, and colorful pencils to draw on it. Your geography notebook is where we'll write down important facts, and those pictures show us some amazing places we'll learn about.

slides.text: We have been exploring the regions of the United States. Last time we studied the Northeast — with its rocky coasts, big cities, and cold winters. Now we travel SOUTH to the Southeast region. This is the land of warm weather, long coastlines, mighty rivers, and ancient mountains. It stretches from Virginia all the way down to Florida and west to Louisiana and Arkansas.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're starting our journey into a new part of the USA, the Southeast! Remember how we learned about the Northeast with its chilly weather and rocky shores? Well, get ready, because we're heading to a place with much warmer air, long sandy beaches, and huge rivers!

slides.text: The Southeast includes 12 states. Starting from the north: Virginia, West Virginia, Kentucky, and Tennessee. Moving south: North Carolina, South Carolina, and Georgia along the Atlantic coast. Then Florida, the peninsula reaching toward the Caribbean. Along the Gulf of Mexico: Alabama, Mississippi, and Louisiana. And inland: Arkansas. Find each state on your map and notice how they fit together.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like a puzzle showing us all the states in the Southeast. We need to find them on our big US map and see where they are. It's like finding all the pieces of a giant puzzle that make up this warm and sunny part of our country.

slides.text: The physical geography is dramatic. The APPALACHIAN MOUNTAINS run along the western edge — they are some of the oldest mountains on Earth. East of the mountains are rolling hills called the PIEDMONT, then flat COASTAL PLAINS stretching to the ocean. The MISSISSIPPI RIVER — America's mightiest river — forms the western boundary, and the GULF OF MEXICO provides a long warm coastline to the south.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to explore some amazing land shapes! We'll see the giant Appalachian Mountains way over on one side, and flat lands called coastal plains that stretch all the way to the ocean. We'll also meet the super-duper Mississippi River, which is like a giant water road!

slides.text: The Southeast has a warm, humid climate with long summers and mild winters. This means a long GROWING SEASON — plants can grow for many months. But the warm Gulf waters also create HURRICANES — powerful storms that can be very destructive. Special places include Florida's EVERGLADES (a vast wetland), North Carolina's OUTER BANKS (barrier islands), and the MISSISSIPPI DELTA where the great river meets the Gulf.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we learn about the weather and some super cool, special spots. The Southeast is warm and has lots of sunshine, which is great for growing things, but it also means big storms called hurricanes can happen near the water. We'll also discover amazing places like watery swamps and islands just off the coast!

slides.prompt:
Complete your Southeast region map:
1. Label all 12 states and their capitals
2. Color the Appalachian Mountains brown
3. Draw and label the Mississippi River, Ohio River, and Tennessee River in blue
4. Mark the Gulf Coast and Atlantic Coast
5. Mark special features: Everglades, Outer Banks, Mississippi Delta
6. In your notebook, create a comparison chart: Northeast vs. Southeast (climate, landforms, bodies of water)
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, it's time to become map masters! You'll get to draw and label all the states we just learned about, color in the big mountains, and draw the amazing rivers in blue. Then, you’ll mark the coastlines and those special places, and make a chart in your notebook comparing this new region to the Northeast.

slides.text: The Southeast region is shaped by water — the Atlantic Ocean, the Gulf of Mexico, and the mighty Mississippi River. Its warm climate, fertile soil, and long coastlines have attracted people for thousands of years. Next time we will explore the history, culture, and economy of this fascinating region.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and locate at least 8 of the 12 Southeast states? Can they identify the Appalachian Mountains, Mississippi River, and Gulf Coast on a map? Can they describe at least 3 ways the Southeast differs from the Northeast?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned all about the Southeast, from its warm weather to its big rivers and mountains. You're becoming a super geography expert, knowing all about where these states are and how they're different from the Northeast. Next time, we'll find out even more exciting things about this amazing region!

parent_notes: Regional geography builds spatial awareness and helps children understand how physical features shape human activity. The Southeast is rich with contrast — ancient mountains and flat plains, vast wetlands and barrier islands, mighty rivers and ocean coastlines. The comparison with the Northeast reinforces learning from the previous unit while highlighting how geography influences climate, economy, and culture. If possible, explore satellite images of the Everglades, the Mississippi Delta, and the Outer Banks online — seeing these features from above is striking. Children may be curious about hurricanes; explain them as powerful storms fueled by warm ocean water. The 12-state list is substantial; focus first on geographic neighbors and build outward.

title: Read Aloud — Shiloh, Chapters 8-10
description: Students continue reading Shiloh by Phyllis Reynolds Naylor, exploring chapters 8-10 where Marty's secret about hiding the dog becomes harder to keep. They discuss the mounting tension, the ethical dilemmas Marty faces, and how lies create more problems even when told for good reasons.
instructions:
1. Review: What has happened in Shiloh so far? Key events and feelings.
2. Read chapter 8 aloud with expression, pausing at tense moments.
3. Discuss: How is Marty's secret affecting his relationships?
4. Read chapter 9 — the tension increases.
5. Pause: What would YOU do in Marty's situation?
6. Read chapter 10 — significant events unfold.
7. Character analysis: How has Marty changed since the beginning?
8. Discuss the theme: Can a lie ever be justified to protect someone?
9. Students write a prediction for what will happen next.
10. Vocabulary work: 3 new words from today's reading.

slides.heading: Shiloh
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our book for today! It tells us we're going to be reading chapters 8, 9, and 10 of Shiloh, and these chapters are all about the big secrets Marty is keeping and how they start to cause problems.

items: Character traits chart from previous sessions
slides.setup_instructions: Bookmark chapters 8-10. Review the story so far: Marty has found an abused dog (Shiloh), hidden it from his family, and is struggling with the secrets and lies this requires. Prepare discussion questions that probe ethical dilemmas without imposing answers. Have the character traits chart available for updating.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our reading supplies ready! You'll need your book, Shiloh, so you can read along with me. We also need your reading journal and a pencil to write down your thoughts, and some blank cards for new words we learn. Don't forget our character chart from before, where we track how Marty is changing.

slides.text: Let us remember where we are in Shiloh. Marty found a beagle he believes is being abused by Judd Travers. He has hidden the dog and built a secret pen in the woods. But keeping this secret means lying to his family — his parents, his sisters. Each lie leads to another lie. Today we will read chapters 8, 9, and 10 to see how Marty's situation unfolds.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's get our minds back into the story. Remember, Marty found Shiloh and he's worried the dog is being treated badly, so he's hidden him in the woods. This means he's had to tell little lies to his mom and dad, and those lies are starting to pile up and make things tricky for him.

slides.text: [Read chapters 8-9 aloud.] Notice how the author builds TENSION — that feeling of something about to go wrong. Marty is trying to do a good thing (protect Shiloh) but the way he is doing it (lying and hiding) creates new problems. Every time someone gets close to discovering the secret, we feel nervous for Marty. This is called SUSPENSE.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for some exciting reading! As I read chapters 8 and 9, pay close attention to how the story feels like it's getting more and more exciting, almost like your heart is beating faster. That's called tension, and it happens when Marty's secret is almost discovered, making us wonder what will happen next.

slides.text: [Read chapter 10 aloud.] This is a turning point in the story. Think about the CONSEQUENCES of Marty's choices. He started with one secret, and it has grown into many lies and difficult situations. The author is showing us something important: even when we have good intentions, dishonesty creates a web that gets harder and harder to untangle.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, chapter 10 is a big one! It's a real turning point where things change a lot because of Marty's choices. The story is showing us that even when you're trying to do something good, like protecting Shiloh, telling lies can create a tangled mess that's hard to get out of.

slides.text: Let us update our character chart. How has Marty CHANGED since chapter 1? He started as an honest boy who discovered something wrong. Now he is keeping secrets, telling lies, and feeling guilty. Is he still a good person? YES — good people sometimes face impossible choices. The question is not whether Marty is good or bad, but what he will DO next to make things right.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's think about Marty! Look at our chart – how has he changed since the very beginning? He started out being really honest, but now he's keeping secrets and feeling bad about it. It shows that even good kids can get into tough spots and have to make difficult decisions.

slides.prompt:
In your reading journal:
1. Write a summary of today's three chapters (5-7 sentences)
2. Update your character traits chart for Marty — add new traits you noticed today
3. Answer this question in a full paragraph: Do you think Marty was right to hide Shiloh? Why or why not? What would you have done differently?
4. Write a prediction: What do you think will happen in the next chapters?
5. Vocabulary: Write definitions for 3 new words from today's reading and use each in a sentence
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to do some super important thinking in your journal! First, write down what happened in these chapters in your own words. Then, add any new things you noticed about Marty to our character chart. After that, write a paragraph telling me if you think Marty did the right thing and what you would have done instead. Finally, make a guess about what you think will happen next in the story!

slides.text: Shiloh is a story about doing the right thing — but it shows that figuring out WHAT the right thing is can be incredibly complicated. Marty loves Shiloh and wants to protect him, but lying creates its own kind of harm. Great books like this do not give easy answers; they make us THINK about what we would do. Next time we will read more to see how Marty resolves his dilemma.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child summarize the key events of chapters 8-10? Can they identify how Marty's character has changed? Can they articulate the ethical dilemma and give a reasoned opinion? Can they make a prediction supported by evidence from the text?
slides.mascot_explanation: We finished reading some really important parts of Shiloh today! You listened carefully to how Marty's secrets made things complicated, and you've thought hard about what makes a choice "right" or "wrong." It's amazing how books can make us think so much, and next time we'll see how Marty figures out his next move.

parent_notes: These chapters intensify the ethical complexity that makes Shiloh such a powerful read-aloud. Marty is caught between two goods (protecting an animal from abuse vs. being honest with his family) and two wrongs (allowing abuse vs. lying). There is no easy answer, and that is the point. Encourage your child to articulate their own position and support it with reasoning — this develops moral thinking and argumentation skills simultaneously. If your child is upset by the tension, reassure them that good authors create difficult situations so characters can find their way through. The vocabulary work builds language skills organically from meaningful context. Consider reading a chapter ahead so you can prepare for emotional moments.

title: Oral Presentation Skills — Voice and Body Language
description: Students practice the physical aspects of public speaking: voice projection, pace, pausing, eye contact, posture, and gestures. They learn that HOW you say something is just as important as WHAT you say, and practice their presentations with a focus on delivery.
instructions:
1. Review: What are the three parts of a presentation? (Hook, body, closing.)
2. Introduce the concept: DELIVERY — how you present matters as much as content.
3. Voice projection: practice speaking loudly enough for the back of the room.
4. Pace: not too fast (audience cannot follow), not too slow (audience loses interest).
5. Pausing: a powerful tool — pause after important points for effect.
6. Eye contact: look at your audience, not your notes — practice the 'triangle' technique.
7. Posture: stand tall, feet planted, hands free (not in pockets).
8. Gestures: use hands to emphasize points, but not too much.
9. Students practice their presentations focusing on one skill at a time.
10. Partner feedback: What did they do well? One suggestion for improvement.

slides.heading: Voice and Body Language
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a book, and it's telling us we're going to learn about how to be awesome speakers by using our voice and our bodies in the best way possible! It's all about making sure everyone can hear and understand you, and that you look and feel super confident when you talk.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up an open area where students can stand and practice speaking. Prepare simple feedback forms with categories: Volume (too quiet / just right / too loud), Speed (too fast / just right / too slow), Eye Contact (good / needs work), and one line for 'Something you did great' and 'One suggestion.' Have the timer ready for 2-minute practice rounds.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us all the cool tools we need to become amazing speakers today! We've got our presentation plans from before, some handy index cards to remind us of our main ideas, a timer to keep us on track, and special feedback forms to help each other get better. We also need a big open space so we can stand up tall and practice moving around, just like real presenters do.

slides.text: On Day 1 you created a great PLAN for your presentation. But a great plan delivered poorly will not reach your audience. Today we learn about DELIVERY — the way you use your voice and body to communicate powerfully. Think of it this way: your plan is the song, and delivery is how you SING it.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is super important because it's about how you SHARE your ideas, not just what your ideas are. Remember how you worked hard on your presentation plan? Well, this is about making sure everyone *hears* and *understands* your plan when you talk. Think of your plan as the music, and delivery is how you sing that song so everyone loves it!

slides.text: VOICE PROJECTION means speaking loudly enough for everyone to hear, without shouting. Imagine your voice is a ball you are throwing to the person sitting farthest away. PACE means speed — speak at a medium speed. Too fast and people cannot follow; too slow and they get bored. PAUSING is the secret weapon: after an important point, STOP for 2-3 seconds. It lets the point sink in.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is teaching us about the magic of our voice and how we talk! "Voice projection" means making sure your voice is loud enough for everyone, even the people way in the back, but not so loud that it sounds like you're yelling. "Pace" is how fast or slow you talk – you want to be just right, not too speedy and not too slow. And "pausing" is like hitting a mini-stop button after a really important idea to let everyone really think about it – it’s a super powerful trick!

slides.text: EYE CONTACT means looking at your audience, not at the floor, ceiling, or your notes. A trick: imagine a triangle — look at someone on the left, then someone on the right, then someone in the middle. Move between these three points. POSTURE means standing straight and tall. Plant your feet shoulder-width apart. Keep your hands free — no fidgeting, no hands in pockets.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we're learning how to connect with the people listening to you. "Eye contact" means looking at your audience, not down at your feet or your notes, and the triangle trick helps you look at different people. "Posture" is about standing up straight and tall with your feet planted, like a strong tree, so you look confident and ready to share.

slides.text: GESTURES bring your words to life. When you say 'three points,' hold up three fingers. When you describe something big, spread your arms. But do not overdo it — constant motion is distracting. The goal is to look CONFIDENT and NATURAL, even if you feel nervous inside. Here is a secret: acting confident MAKES you feel more confident. Let us practice!
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is about using your hands and body to make your presentation exciting! When you use "gestures," like holding up fingers to count or spreading your arms wide for something big, it helps your audience understand your words even better. The trick is to use them naturally to show what you mean, not too much, so you look and feel confident, which actually helps you *be* more confident!

slides.prompt:
Practice your presentation in rounds:
Round 1: Focus ONLY on voice projection — speak so the farthest person can hear clearly
Round 2: Focus on pace and pausing — slow down, add 2-second pauses after main points
Round 3: Focus on eye contact — use the triangle technique, look up from notes
Round 4: Full practice with a partner — combine all skills
Partner gives feedback: one thing done well, one suggestion
Time limit: 2 minutes per presentation
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to shine! We're going to practice your presentation in a few rounds, focusing on one skill at a time. First, you'll practice just speaking loudly and clearly, then you'll work on your talking speed and adding pauses, then you'll practice looking at different people. Finally, you'll do a full practice with a partner, and they'll tell you one thing you did great and one idea to make it even better. You've got this!

slides.text: You are becoming a real speaker! Remember: projection so everyone hears, pace so everyone follows, pauses for impact, eye contact for connection, and confident posture. The more you practice, the more natural these skills become. Professional speakers practice their talks many, many times. Your presentation day is coming soon — keep practicing!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child project their voice appropriately? Do they maintain a steady pace with intentional pauses? Can they make eye contact with the audience? Do they stand with confident posture? Can they give and receive constructive feedback?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've done such a fantastic job practicing all those presentation skills today! You learned how to project your voice so everyone can hear, control your pace and use pauses, make eye contact to connect with people, and stand tall with confidence. The more you practice these things, the easier and more natural they become, just like riding a bike!

parent_notes: Delivery skills are best learned through practice, not lecture. The round-by-round approach isolates each skill so children are not overwhelmed trying to do everything at once. Common challenges at this age: speaking too quickly (nervousness), looking down at notes, fidgeting, and speaking in a monotone. Address each gently and specifically: 'Try looking up after each sentence' is more helpful than 'Make more eye contact.' At home, practice in front of a mirror, stuffed animals, or family members. Video recording (with the child's permission) can be a powerful learning tool — children are often surprised by how they appear. Always lead with encouragement before suggestions. The 'triangle technique' for eye contact gives children a concrete strategy instead of the vague instruction to 'look at your audience.'

title: Fractions Review — Comparing and Ordering Fractions
description: Students review how to compare fractions with the same denominator, compare fractions with the same numerator, and order sets of fractions from least to greatest. They use fraction manipulatives and number lines to build visual understanding of fraction size.
instructions:
1. Review: What does the numerator tell us? The denominator?
2. Same denominator comparison: 3/8 vs. 5/8 — same size pieces, more pieces wins.
3. Same numerator comparison: 1/3 vs. 1/6 — same number of pieces, bigger pieces wins.
4. Demonstrate with fraction circles: physically stack and compare.
5. Number line comparisons: place fractions and see which is farther right.
6. Introduce the symbols: > (greater than), < (less than), = (equal to).
7. Practice: students compare 10 pairs of fractions using manipulatives.
8. Ordering challenge: arrange a set of 5 fractions from least to greatest.
9. Students record comparisons using proper symbols in notebooks.
10. Fraction comparison game: draw two cards, compare, bigger fraction wins the round.

slides.heading: Comparing Fractions
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our fraction adventure! It's showing us that we're going to learn all about comparing fractions, which just means figuring out which fraction is bigger or smaller, kind of like deciding who gets the bigger slice of pizza.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 10 fraction comparison pairs of varying difficulty. Include same-denominator pairs (3/8 vs 5/8), same-numerator pairs (1/3 vs 1/6), and some equivalent fractions (2/4 vs 1/2). Create fraction cards for the game: fractions from 1/2, 1/3, 2/3, 1/4, 2/4, 3/4, 1/6, 5/6, 1/8, 3/8, 5/8, 7/8. Have the number line clearly marked.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll need for our fraction fun. We've got fraction circles or bars to see the pieces, a number line to help us line them up, special symbol cards for greater than and less than, and some fraction cards for a game. You'll need to gather these up so we're ready to go!

slides.text: Today we learn to COMPARE fractions — to figure out which is BIGGER. There are two easy rules. Rule 1: SAME DENOMINATOR — the pieces are the same size, so whoever has MORE pieces wins. Compare 3/8 and 5/8: both have eighth-size pieces, but 5 pieces is more than 3 pieces, so 5/8 > 3/8. Easy!
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about comparing fractions when the bottom numbers, the denominators, are the same. Think of it like having the same size pizza slices – if you have more slices, you have more pizza, right? So, if the denominators are the same, the fraction with the bigger top number, the numerator, is the winner!

slides.text: Rule 2: SAME NUMERATOR — you have the same NUMBER of pieces, so whoever has BIGGER pieces wins. Compare 1/3 and 1/6: you have 1 piece of each, but thirds are BIGGER than sixths (cutting into fewer pieces makes each piece larger). So 1/3 > 1/6. Remember: BIGGER denominator means SMALLER pieces!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at comparing fractions when the top numbers, the numerators, are the same. Imagine you have one cookie, but one is cut into 3 big pieces and the other is cut into 6 tiny pieces. The one with the bigger pieces (thirds!) is more cookie, even though you only have one piece of each. So, a bigger denominator means smaller pieces!

slides.text: Let us PROVE it with fraction circles. Stack 3/8 on top of 5/8 — you can see 5/8 covers more space. Stack 1/3 on top of 1/6 — the third is clearly bigger. The number line confirms it too: whichever fraction is farther to the RIGHT is larger. Place 1/3 and 1/6 on the number line — 1/3 is farther right.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us how to *see* which fractions are bigger. We can stack our fraction pieces to compare them, and you'll see that the bigger fraction covers more space. We can also use the number line – whichever number is farther to the right is the bigger one, just like on a ruler!

slides.text: We use special symbols: the GREATER THAN sign > points to the smaller number (think of it as a hungry alligator that always eats the bigger number). 5/8 > 3/8. The LESS THAN sign < points to the bigger number. 1/6 < 1/3. And EQUAL means the fractions are the same size: 1/2 = 2/4. Now we can ORDER fractions from least to greatest — just compare them two at a time and arrange.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we learn the secret code for comparing fractions! The hungry alligator symbol ">" always opens its mouth towards the bigger number, like it wants to eat it. The "<" symbol points to the smaller number. And when two fractions are exactly the same size, we use the "=" sign. We can use these symbols to put fractions in order from smallest to biggest.

slides.prompt:
Fraction comparison practice:
1. Compare these pairs using >, <, or = (use fraction circles to check):
   2/5 ___ 4/5 | 1/4 ___ 1/8 | 3/6 ___ 1/2 | 5/8 ___ 3/8 | 1/3 ___ 1/5
   2/4 ___ 2/6 | 7/8 ___ 3/8 | 1/2 ___ 1/6 | 4/6 ___ 2/6 | 3/4 ___ 3/8
2. Order from least to greatest: 1/2, 1/4, 3/4, 1/8, 7/8
3. Fraction Card Game: Draw two cards, compare, bigger fraction wins the round. Play 10 rounds and record results.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to practice! You'll get to compare lots of different fractions, first by looking at them and then by using your fraction circles to check. After that, you'll get to put a group of fractions in order from smallest to biggest, and then we'll play a fun game where you draw fraction cards and decide who wins the round!

slides.text: Comparing fractions becomes easy when you remember the two rules: same denominator, more pieces wins; same numerator, bigger pieces wins. And when in doubt, use your fraction circles or the number line — they never lie! Being able to compare fractions helps you in cooking (is 1/3 cup more than 1/4 cup?), measuring, sharing fairly, and all of higher mathematics.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly compare fractions with the same denominator? Same numerator? Can they use >, <, and = symbols correctly? Can they order a set of fractions from least to greatest? Can they verify comparisons with manipulatives?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! You've learned how to become a fraction comparing superstar by using those two super helpful rules and checking your answers with your fraction tools. Remember, comparing fractions is useful for lots of things, from cooking to sharing, and you've totally mastered it today!

parent_notes: Comparing fractions is where many children first encounter counterintuitive math: 1/3 is bigger than 1/6 even though 3 is less than 6. The physical fraction circles are essential here — children need to SEE that cutting something into more pieces makes each piece smaller. The two rules (same denominator: compare numerators; same numerator: compare denominators) provide a framework, but understanding WHY comes from hands-on experience. The card game makes practice fun and repeatable. At home, use real-world comparisons: Would you rather have 1/4 of a pizza or 1/8? Would 3/4 of an hour or 1/2 of an hour give you more playtime? These concrete connections build lasting understanding.

title: Healthy Habits — Nutrition and the Food Groups
description: Students explore the fundamentals of nutrition by learning about the five food groups, what each provides for the body, and how to build a balanced plate. They analyze sample meals, categorize foods, and design their own healthy daily menu.
instructions:
1. Ask: Why do we eat food? (Energy, growth, repair, health.)
2. Introduce the five food groups: fruits, vegetables, grains, protein, dairy.
3. Fruits and vegetables: vitamins, minerals, fiber — 'rainbow eating.'
4. Grains: energy from carbohydrates — whole grains vs. refined grains.
5. Protein: building and repairing muscles — meat, beans, nuts, eggs.
6. Dairy: calcium for strong bones — milk, cheese, yogurt.
7. The balanced plate: half fruits/vegetables, quarter grains, quarter protein, side of dairy.
8. Activity: categorize a list of 20 foods into the correct food group.
9. Students design a healthy daily menu (breakfast, lunch, dinner, 2 snacks).
10. Discuss: What happens when we eat too much of one group and not enough of another?
materials_needed: Paper plate for balanced plate activity

slides.heading: Healthy Habits
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our book for today! It's called "Healthy Habits" and it's all about something super important: "Nutrition and the Food Groups." This means we're going to learn how the food we eat helps our bodies grow big and strong, and how to pick the best foods to eat.

slides.setup_instructions: Display a food group poster or create one showing the five groups with examples. Prepare a paper plate divided into sections matching the balanced plate model (half for fruits/veggies, quarter for grains, quarter for protein, small circle for dairy). Gather or print food picture cards representing each group. Have a menu template with spaces for breakfast, lunch, dinner, and two snacks.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at all these cool things we need for our adventure today! We have a poster showing the food groups, a special plate that's already drawn with sections, lots of little cards with pictures of different foods, colored pencils, a notebook, and a paper to plan our meals. You'll need to gather these up, maybe with a grown-up's help, so we can start exploring all the yummy foods!

slides.text: Your body is like an amazing machine, and FOOD is its fuel. But not just any fuel — your body needs DIFFERENT types of fuel for different jobs. Fruits and vegetables give you VITAMINS and MINERALS to fight sickness. Grains give you ENERGY to run and think. Protein BUILDS and REPAIRS your muscles. Dairy makes your BONES strong. You need ALL of them every day!
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is telling us why we even need to eat food. Think of your body like a super cool car – it needs the right kind of fuel to go, right? Food is that fuel! Different foods do different jobs, like giving you energy to play, helping you grow taller, fixing you up if you get a boo-boo, and keeping you from getting sick. We need all sorts of foods to make sure our body-car runs perfectly!

slides.text: FRUITS AND VEGETABLES are nature's superfoods. They come in every color of the rainbow, and each color has different nutrients. Red tomatoes have lycopene. Orange carrots have vitamin A. Green spinach has iron. Try to eat a RAINBOW every day! Vegetables and fruits should fill HALF your plate at every meal — that is how important they are.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're talking about fruits and vegetables! See how they say "eat a rainbow"? That's because fruits and veggies come in all sorts of amazing colors, and each color gives your body different super powers, like vitamins and minerals that help you fight off colds. They're so important that they should take up half of your plate every time you eat a meal!

slides.text: GRAINS give you energy — they are your body's fuel for running, playing, and thinking. Bread, rice, pasta, oatmeal, and cereal are all grains. WHOLE grains (brown rice, whole wheat bread, oatmeal) are better than refined grains (white bread, white rice) because they keep the nutritious outer shell. PROTEIN builds muscle and repairs your body — you find it in meat, fish, beans, lentils, eggs, nuts, and tofu.
slides.mascot_explanation: This next slide is all about grains and protein. Grains, like bread and rice, are like the energy bars for your body, giving you power to run and learn. Protein, found in things like chicken, beans, and eggs, is like the building blocks that help your muscles grow strong and fix themselves. It's important to choose whole grains, like oatmeal, because they give you even more good stuff!

slides.text: DAIRY gives you CALCIUM for strong bones and teeth — milk, cheese, yogurt, and butter. Some people use alternatives like almond milk or soy milk that are fortified with calcium. Now look at your plate: HALF should be fruits and vegetables, one QUARTER should be grains, one QUARTER should be protein, and a small serving of dairy on the side. This is the formula for a BALANCED meal!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for the balanced plate! Dairy foods, like milk and cheese, give you calcium, which is like cement for making your bones super strong. Now, look at the drawing of the plate: half of it should be colorful fruits and veggies, one quarter should be energy-giving grains, another quarter should be muscle-building protein, and a little bit of dairy on the side. This is the secret recipe for a super healthy meal!

slides.prompt:
Three activities:
1. Food Sorting: Categorize these 20 food cards into the correct food group. Some foods fit more than one group!
2. Balanced Plate: On your paper plate, draw or paste a balanced meal that includes all five food groups in the right proportions
3. Menu Designer: Plan a full day of healthy eating — breakfast, lunch, dinner, and 2 snacks. Make sure each meal has at least 3 food groups. Write your menu on the planning template.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the chef and the scientist! First, you'll sort all those food picture cards into their right food groups – it's like a fun puzzle! Then, you'll use your special plate and colored pencils to draw or paste pictures of a balanced meal, making sure you have all the right parts. Finally, you'll use the menu planner to create a whole day of yummy, healthy meals and snacks!

slides.text: What you eat every day affects how you feel, how well you think, how fast you grow, and how healthy you stay. You do not need to be perfect — but by knowing the five food groups and aiming for a balanced plate at every meal, you are making choices that help your body do its best work. Remember: eat a rainbow of fruits and vegetables, choose whole grains, get enough protein, and include dairy for strong bones.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name the five food groups? Can they categorize foods correctly? Do they understand the balanced plate model? Can they explain what each food group provides for the body? Can they plan a balanced meal?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned all about the five food groups and how to make a super balanced plate. Eating healthy food is like giving your body the best tools to grow, play, and think. You learned how to pick foods that give you energy, help you grow, and keep you strong and healthy. You are now a healthy habits expert!

parent_notes: Nutrition education empowers children to make informed food choices rather than just following rules. The five food group model is simplified for this age but provides a solid framework. Avoid labeling foods as 'good' or 'bad' — instead use 'everyday foods' and 'sometimes foods.' The balanced plate model (MyPlate) is the current USDA recommendation and is more intuitive than the old food pyramid. Be sensitive to different dietary needs and cultural food traditions — there are many ways to eat a balanced diet. If your family is vegetarian, vegan, or has allergies, adapt the examples accordingly. The menu planning activity gives children agency and can be used for real meal planning at home. Involve children in grocery shopping and cooking to reinforce these concepts practically.

title: Music — Song Writing Workshop Part 1
description: Students explore the basics of songwriting by learning about verse and chorus structure, creating simple lyrics about a topic they care about, and setting their words to a familiar melody. This creative exercise combines language arts with musical understanding.
instructions:
1. Listen to a simple, well-known song — identify the verse and chorus.
2. Explain structure: verse tells the story (changes each time), chorus is the main message (repeats).
3. Other parts: sometimes an intro, sometimes a bridge (different section between choruses).
4. Discuss rhyming in songs — many lyrics rhyme at the end of lines, but not always.
5. Choose a topic together as a class: seasons, friendship, a favorite animal.
6. Write a chorus together: 4 lines, simple message, rhyming couplets.
7. Students write their own verse: 4 lines that tell a specific story about the topic.
8. Try singing the lyrics to a familiar tune (Twinkle Twinkle, Row Your Boat).
9. Share verses and give encouraging feedback.
10. Discuss how melody and lyrics work together to create feeling.

slides.heading: Song Writing Workshop
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us the name of our fun activity today: a Song Writing Workshop! We're going to learn how to put words together to make our own songs, and we'll start by understanding the different parts of a song. Isn't it exciting to become a songwriter?

items: Printed lyrics of a simple, well-known song
Rhyming word lists organized by ending sound
Audio player for listening to example songs
slides.setup_instructions: Select a simple song with clear verse-chorus structure that children know (e.g., 'You Are My Sunshine,' 'This Land Is Your Land,' or a simple pop song). Print the lyrics so children can see the structure. Prepare rhyming word lists organized by common endings (-ay, -ight, -ound, -een, -ove, etc.). Have chart paper ready for collaborative writing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's see what we need for our songwriting adventure! We have the words to a song we know, which will help us see how songs are built. We'll also need paper and pencils to write our own ideas, and some lists of words that sound alike, called rhyming words. We'll use a music player to hear some examples, and a big piece of paper called chart paper where we'll write some lyrics together as a class.

slides.text: Songs are poems set to music! And just like stories, songs have a STRUCTURE. Most songs have two main parts: VERSES and a CHORUS. The CHORUS is the main message of the song — it REPEATS the same words every time. The VERSES tell different parts of the story — the words CHANGE each time but the melody stays the same. Listen to this song and see if you can hear the pattern.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is teaching us about the building blocks of songs, like how a house has walls and a roof! Most songs have two main parts: verses, which tell the story and change each time, and a chorus, which is like the song's big idea and it repeats over and over. We'll listen to a song together to hear how these parts fit.

slides.text: Many song lyrics RHYME — the last words of certain lines sound alike. 'Twinkle twinkle little STAR, how I wonder what you ARE.' Star and are rhyme! Rhyming makes lyrics catchy and easy to remember. But not all songs rhyme — some use rhythm and repetition instead. Today we will try rhyming because it is fun and musical.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we're learning about rhyming! You know how in "Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star," the words "star" and "are" sound the same at the end? That's rhyming, and it makes songs super catchy and fun to sing. We'll use rhyming words today to make our own song lyrics sound musical.

slides.text: Let us write a CHORUS together! Our topic is [chosen topic]. The chorus should express the MAIN FEELING about this topic in 4 short lines. Lines 1 and 2 should rhyme with each other, and lines 3 and 4 should rhyme. Use your rhyming word lists to find words that work. Remember: keep it SIMPLE — the best choruses use easy words that everyone can sing along to.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to create our chorus together! A chorus is the part of the song that repeats the main message, so we need to think about the big feeling we want to share about our topic. We'll write four lines, and the first two lines will rhyme, and the last two lines will rhyme, kind of like a little song within our song!

slides.text: Now YOU write a VERSE — 4 lines that tell a specific detail or story about the topic. Your verse is personal — it is YOUR take on the topic. Maybe you write about a specific moment, a feeling, or an image. Try to make lines 2 and 4 rhyme. Then we will try fitting your lyrics to a familiar melody. If the words do not fit perfectly, we can adjust — songwriters do this all the time!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your turn to shine and write your very own verse! A verse is like a little story that adds to the main idea of the chorus. Think of a specific detail or a feeling about our topic and write four lines about it. We'll try to make the second and fourth lines rhyme, and don't worry if it's not perfect – songwriters change their words all the time to make them sound just right!

slides.prompt:
Write your own song verse:
1. Choose the topic (the one our class selected)
2. Write 4 lines that describe something specific about the topic
3. Try to rhyme lines 2 and 4 (use the rhyming word list for help)
4. Combine your verse with our class chorus
5. Try singing it to the tune of a familiar song
6. Share your verse with a partner and practice singing together
Bonus: Try writing a second verse with a different detail about the same topic
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, time to put on your songwriter hat and create your verse! First, remember the topic our class chose. Then, write four lines telling me something specific about it, and try to make lines two and four rhyme using our word lists. After that, we'll put your verse together with our class chorus and try singing it to a tune you already know, like "Row, Row, Row Your Boat"!

slides.text: You are songwriters! You learned that songs have structure (verses and choruses), that lyrics often rhyme, and that words and melody work together to create feelings. The songs you hear on the radio all started just like this — someone with a feeling and some words. Next time we will refine our songs, add melody ideas, and perform for each other.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify verse and chorus in a song? Can they write a 4-line verse with at least one rhyming pair? Can they explain the difference between verse (changing story) and chorus (repeating message)? Can they sing their lyrics to a familiar tune?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You’re officially songwriters who understand how songs are built with verses and choruses, and how rhyming makes lyrics fun. You learned that putting words together with a melody makes us feel things, just like all the amazing songs we hear every day. You should be super proud of creating your own lyrics today!

parent_notes: Songwriting combines creative writing, musical understanding, and self-expression in a uniquely engaging way. Children at this age love music and often naturally make up songs, so this lesson channels that impulse into structured learning. The use of familiar melodies removes the barrier of composing music from scratch, letting children focus on lyrics. Rhyming develops phonological awareness (important for reading) while the verse-chorus structure teaches organizational thinking. Do not worry about musical quality — the goal is creative expression and understanding song structure. Encourage your child to keep writing songs at home. Some children who resist traditional writing will eagerly write song lyrics because the format feels different and fun.

title: Healthy Habits — Sleep, Exercise, and Screen Time
description: Students learn about three pillars of physical health beyond nutrition: adequate sleep, regular exercise, and balanced screen time. They explore why each matters for growing bodies and minds, set personal goals, and create a daily health habits tracker.
instructions:
1. Connect to nutrition lesson: food is one part of health. What else matters?
2. Sleep: children ages 6-9 need 9-12 hours per night. Why? Growth, brain processing, healing.
3. What happens when we do not sleep enough? Trouble focusing, grumpy, get sick more.
4. Good sleep habits: consistent bedtime, dark room, no screens before bed, calming routine.
5. Exercise: 60 minutes of active play per day. Why? Strong muscles, healthy heart, better mood.
6. Types of exercise: running, swimming, dancing, sports, climbing, biking, yoga.
7. Screen time: educational vs. entertainment screens. The 2-hour guideline.
8. Balance: the goal is a daily routine that includes good sleep, active play, AND screen limits.
9. Students create a personal 'Healthy Habits Tracker' for one week.
10. Set 3 personal goals: one for sleep, one for exercise, one for screen time.

slides.heading: Healthy Habits
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into being super healthy! It's showing us the three main things we're going to learn about today: getting enough sleep, moving our bodies with exercise, and making sure we don't spend too much time looking at screens. These are all super important for growing up strong and feeling great!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a weekly tracker grid with rows for Sleep (bedtime, wake time, total hours), Exercise (type and minutes), and Screen Time (total minutes). Have a goal-setting worksheet with space for 3 goals and action steps. Consider having children track their habits for a full week as a take-home activity.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at all these cool things we get to use for our healthy habits project! We have a poster that will tell us lots of important stuff, a special paper called a template to track our habits each week, and colorful pencils to make our trackers look awesome. We also have a worksheet to help us set goals and a notebook to write down our thoughts, so we can become healthy habit experts!

slides.text: We learned about nutrition — feeding your body the right fuel. But food is only ONE part of being healthy. Today we learn about three more pillars of health: SLEEP, EXERCISE, and SCREEN TIME BALANCE. Together with good nutrition, these four things determine how well your body grows, how clearly your mind thinks, and how good you FEEL every day.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, we already learned that eating healthy food is like giving our bodies good fuel, right? Well, this slide is telling us that food is just *one* piece of the puzzle for being healthy. Today, we're going to discover three more super important parts: getting enough sleep, playing and moving our bodies, and finding a good balance with screen time. These four things together help us grow, think clearly, and feel our best every single day!

slides.text: SLEEP is when your body does its most important work. While you sleep, your body GROWS (growth hormone is released at night), your brain ORGANIZES everything you learned that day (like filing papers into folders), and your immune system REPAIRS damage and fights germs. Children your age need 9-12 hours EVERY night. That means if you wake up at 7 AM, you should be asleep by 9 PM — and falling asleep takes time, so be in bed by 8:30!
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is all about SLEEP, and it’s super important because while you’re snoozing, your body is actually doing some of its most important jobs! Your body grows, your brain sorts and remembers everything you learned, and your body fights off yucky germs. Kids your age need about 9 to 12 hours of sleep *every single night* to do all this important work. That’s a lot of sleep, but it helps you be strong and smart!

slides.text: EXERCISE means moving your body actively for at least 60 minutes every day. This does not have to be all at once — recess, walking, playing outside, riding a bike, dancing, swimming, or any sport counts! Exercise makes your heart strong, your muscles powerful, your bones dense, and here is the amazing part: it makes your BRAIN work better too. Children who exercise regularly focus better, learn faster, and feel happier.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's talk about EXERCISE! This means getting your body moving in an active way for at least 60 minutes every day – like playing tag, riding your bike, dancing, or playing sports. Moving your body makes your heart strong, your muscles powerful, and guess what? It even helps your brain work better, making it easier to focus and feel happy!

slides.text: SCREEN TIME means time spent looking at screens — TV, tablets, phones, computers. Some screen time is educational and valuable, but too much replaces exercise, sleep, and face-to-face time with friends and family. A good guideline: no more than 2 hours of recreational screen time per day. And here is an important rule: NO SCREENS for at least 1 hour before bedtime — the blue light from screens tricks your brain into thinking it is daytime and makes it harder to fall asleep.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is about SCREEN TIME, which is the time we spend looking at TVs, tablets, or computers. While some screen time can be fun and even teach us new things, spending too much time on screens can take away from playing, sleeping, or talking with people. A good rule is to try and limit the fun screen time to about 2 hours a day, and it's super important to turn off screens at least an hour before bedtime so your brain can get ready to sleep.

slides.prompt:
Create your personal Healthy Habits plan:
1. Design a weekly tracker with rows for: Bedtime, Wake Time, Hours of Sleep, Exercise Type, Exercise Minutes, Screen Time Minutes
2. Color-code it: green for meeting the goal, yellow for close, red for needs improvement
3. Set 3 personal goals:
   - Sleep goal (e.g., 'In bed by 8:30 every school night')
   - Exercise goal (e.g., 'Play actively outside for 30 minutes after school')
   - Screen time goal (e.g., 'No screens after dinner')
4. Write one action step for each goal
5. Take your tracker home and fill it in every day for one week!
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to become a Healthy Habits expert by making your very own plan! First, grab your tracker template and use your colored pencils to draw a chart with spaces for bedtime, when you wake up, how long you slept, what exercise you did and for how long, and how much screen time you had. Then, pick three things you want to get better at – maybe going to bed a little earlier, playing outside for longer, or having less screen time after dinner – and write those down as your goals. Finally, color-code your tracker with green, yellow, and red to show how well you're doing each day, and take it home to fill it out all week!

slides.text: Your body is the only one you get, and how you take care of it NOW affects how it serves you for your ENTIRE life. Good nutrition, adequate sleep, regular exercise, and balanced screen time are not rules made up to limit your fun — they are the recipe for feeling GREAT, thinking clearly, growing strong, and being happy. Track your habits this week and see how small changes make a big difference in how you feel.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why sleep is important for growth and learning? Can they state the recommended hours of sleep for their age? Can they describe benefits of daily exercise? Do they understand the concept of screen time balance? Can they set realistic personal health goals?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you’ve done such a fantastic job learning about all the ways to take care of your amazing body! Remember, eating well, sleeping enough, exercising, and balancing screen time aren't just rules, they are the secret recipe for feeling awesome, thinking clearly, and growing up strong. By tracking your habits this week, you’ll see how making even small changes can make a big difference in how happy and energetic you feel every single day!

parent_notes: This lesson empowers children with knowledge about their own health, which is foundational to the Montessori value of independence and self-care. The recommended guidelines (9-12 hours sleep, 60 minutes exercise, limited screen time) come from the American Academy of Pediatrics. Be realistic about your family's situation — the goal is improvement, not perfection. The weekly tracker makes health habits visible and creates accountability without judgment. Children are more likely to follow through on goals they set themselves rather than goals imposed on them. The screen time conversation should be balanced: screens are tools that can be educational, but physical activity, sleep, and real-world interaction should take priority. Model healthy habits yourself — children learn more from what they see than what they are told.

title: Oral Presentation Skills — Using Visual Aids
description: Students learn how to enhance their presentations with visual aids — posters, drawings, props, or simple slideshows. They explore the principles of effective visual design: simplicity, readability, and relevance, and create visual supports for their own presentations.
instructions:
1. Review delivery skills from Day 2: voice, posture, eye contact.
2. Ask: What do you remember more — hearing facts or SEEING them? Visual aids help audiences remember.
3. Types of visual aids: posters, drawings, photos, objects/props, charts, diagrams.
