4. Principles of good visuals: BIG enough to see, SIMPLE (not too many words), RELEVANT (supports your point).
5. Show examples: a good poster (few words, big image) vs. a bad poster (too much text, tiny images).
6. Rule of thumb: no more than 5 words per line, no more than 5 lines per poster.
7. Discuss when to SHOW the visual: introduce it, point to it, then put it down.
8. Students plan their visual aid: what type, what content, what size.
9. Students create their visual aid for their presentation.
10. Practice: present with the visual aid — does it help or distract?
materials_needed: Props or objects related to topics

slides.heading: Visual Aids
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure today! It tells us we're going to learn about "Visual Aids" and how they can make our presentations super exciting, like bringing them to life.

items: Any props or objects students want to use
slides.setup_instructions: Set up art stations with poster materials. Show examples of effective and ineffective visual aids (make a 'good' poster with a big image and few words, and a 'bad' poster crammed with tiny text). Have a variety of materials available: poster board, construction paper, markers, printed images if available. Encourage students to think about their specific topic and what visual would be most helpful.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at all these cool art supplies! We have poster boards and big paper for drawing, thick markers and colored pencils to make our pictures bright and bold, and even a ruler to help us draw straight lines. We also have some special things called "props" if you want to bring a real object to show, and don't forget your presentation plan from yesterday – that's like our map! You'll need to grab these with a grown-up's help to get ready for some creative fun.

slides.text: You have a great presentation plan and you have practiced your delivery. Now we add the finishing touch: VISUAL AIDS. A visual aid is anything your audience can SEE that helps them understand and remember your message. It might be a poster, a drawing, a chart, a photograph, or even a real object. Studies show that people remember 80% of what they see and do, but only 20% of what they hear!
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is telling us that after we've practiced talking and standing tall for our presentation, we're going to add something special: visual aids! Think of a visual aid as anything your audience can *see* that helps them understand your talk better, like a cool picture or a poster. It's like when you see a picture in a book instead of just reading words – pictures help us remember things way better!

slides.text: There are three rules for great visual aids. Rule 1: BIG ENOUGH TO SEE — if the person in the back row cannot read it, it is too small. Use thick markers and large letters. Rule 2: SIMPLE — a visual should have very few words. No one wants to read a paragraph on a poster! Use pictures, diagrams, or just key words. Rule 3: RELEVANT — every visual should support what you are SAYING. Do not add decorations that do not connect to your topic.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this slide gives us three super important rules for making our visual aids awesome. First, it has to be BIG enough for everyone to see, even the kids in the very back row. Second, it needs to be SIMPLE, meaning not too many words – just the most important ones, maybe with a big picture. And third, it has to be RELEVANT, which means it needs to connect directly to what you're talking about, like a picture of a lion if you're talking about lions!

slides.text: Look at these two posters. This one has a big, clear image in the center, a title at the top in large letters, and three key words below. You can understand it from across the room. THIS one has 50 words in tiny writing, a small picture in the corner, and five different colors. You cannot read it and it is confusing. Which would YOU rather look at during a presentation? Simple and clear ALWAYS wins.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these two posters – one is amazing and the other is kind of a mess! The good poster has a big, clear picture and just a few words at the top, so you know exactly what it's about right away. The other poster has tons of tiny words and a small picture, making it hard to see and understand. This slide reminds us that simple and clear visuals are always the best way to go!

slides.text: When you USE your visual during the presentation, follow these steps: 1) INTRODUCE it: 'I made a poster to show you...' 2) HOLD it up or point to it so everyone can see. 3) EXPLAIN what it shows — do not just show it silently. 4) PUT IT DOWN when you move to the next point so it does not distract. The visual supports YOUR words — you are still the star of the presentation, not the poster!
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us how to use our visual aid when we're actually giving our presentation. First, you tell everyone you have something to show them, like saying "I have a poster here!" Then, you hold it up so everyone can see, and explain what's on it. After that, it's important to put it down so it doesn't distract anyone, because *you* are still the main star of the show!

slides.prompt:
Create your visual aid:
1. Decide what type of visual will best support YOUR presentation (poster, drawing, chart, prop, or combination)
2. Plan your visual on scratch paper first — sketch the layout
3. Create the visual: remember BIG, SIMPLE, RELEVANT
4. For posters: maximum 5 words per line, use thick markers, include one strong image
5. Practice presenting WITH your visual aid
6. Get a partner's feedback: Can they see it? Does it help them understand?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to make your own visual aid! First, think about what would best help your audience understand your presentation – maybe a poster, a drawing, or even a prop. Then, sketch your idea on some scrap paper to plan it out. When you make the real thing, remember the rules: make it big, keep it simple, and make sure it's relevant to your topic, using thick markers and not too many words. After you finish, practice showing it while you talk!

slides.text: A great visual aid does not have to be fancy — it has to be CLEAR. The best visuals are simple, large, and directly connected to what you are saying. Remember: you are the presenter, and the visual is your helper. Practice presenting with your visual aid at home. On presentation day, you will have your plan, your delivery skills, AND your visual aid — you are going to be amazing!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the three rules of effective visual aids (big, simple, relevant)? Did they create a visual that supports their presentation content? Can they use the visual during their talk without it becoming a distraction? Can they critique sample visuals for effectiveness?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've made an amazing visual aid! Remember, the best ones aren't always the fanciest, they're just super clear and easy to understand. You did a great job making something big, simple, and connected to your presentation, and practicing with it means you'll be a fantastic presenter. You've got this!

parent_notes: Visual aids give children a concrete focus during presentations, which actually reduces nervousness — they have something to hold, point to, and reference. The three rules (big, simple, relevant) apply to all visual communication and serve children well throughout their education. Resist the urge to make the poster for your child — even a child-made poster with imperfect lettering is more authentic and educationally valuable than a parent-produced masterpiece. If your child wants to use a real object as a prop, encourage it — props create memorable moments. The key insight is that visuals support the speaker rather than replace them. If your child reads every word off their poster, they are using it as a script rather than a visual aid. Help them practice the introduce-show-explain-put down sequence.

title: Fractions Review — Adding Fractions with Same Denominators
description: Students review adding fractions that share the same denominator, understanding that when the pieces are the same size, you simply count them up. They use fraction manipulatives to visualize the addition process and practice with both proper fractions and results that form wholes.
instructions:
1. Review: When fractions have the same denominator, the pieces are the same size.
2. Adding same-denominator fractions: just add the numerators, keep the denominator.
3. Demonstrate with fraction circles: 1/4 + 2/4 — place pieces together — equals 3/4.
4. Show on number line: start at 1/4, jump forward 2/4, land on 3/4.
5. What if the sum equals a whole? 3/4 + 1/4 = 4/4 = 1 whole.
6. What if the sum is more than a whole? 3/4 + 3/4 = 6/4 = 1 and 2/4 = 1 and 1/2.
7. Practice 8 addition problems with fraction circles.
8. Write the equations in notebooks with proper notation.
9. Word problems: 'You ate 2/8 of the pizza and your sister ate 3/8. How much was eaten?'
10. Challenge: Can the student create their own fraction addition word problem?

slides.heading: Adding Fractions
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing our topic: adding fractions! We're going to learn about adding fractions that have the same bottom number, which makes things super easy because the pieces are all the same size.

items: Fraction circles (multiple sets for sums greater than 1)
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare multiple sets of fraction circles so students can make sums greater than 1 whole. Extend the number line to 2 to accommodate improper fractions. Write 8 addition problems of increasing difficulty. Create word problem cards with real-world fraction scenarios. Include problems where the sum equals exactly 1 and problems where it exceeds 1.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll need for our fraction adventure! We've got these colorful fraction circles – think of them like pizza slices, but for fractions. We also have a number line, which is like a road for numbers, and our math notebooks. You'll need to ask a grown-up to help you gather these things so we can get started.

slides.text: Adding fractions with the SAME denominator is the easiest fraction operation. Think about it: if all the pieces are the SAME SIZE, you just COUNT how many you have! 1/4 + 2/4 means 1 quarter-piece plus 2 quarter-pieces equals 3 quarter-pieces: 3/4. The denominator stays the same because the SIZE of the pieces has not changed — you just have MORE of them.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the super-secret trick for adding fractions with the same bottom number! Since all the pieces are the same size, you just count how many pieces you have. So, if you have 1 piece of a certain size and then get 2 more pieces of that *exact same size*, you just add the numbers on top to get 3 pieces! The bottom number stays the same because the size of the pieces didn't change.

slides.text: Let us prove it with fraction circles. Place 1/4 piece on the table. Now place 2/4 (two quarter pieces) next to it. Push them together. Compare the combined pieces to a 3/4 piece — they are exactly the same! On the number line: start at 1/4, jump forward 2/4, and you land on 3/4. Both methods confirm the answer.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to see this trick in action! We're going to use those fraction circles to *see* how adding works. Imagine putting one slice of pizza on the table, and then adding two more slices of the *same size* – you can easily see you have three slices total! The number line shows us the same thing, like taking little hops to get to the answer.

slides.text: Something interesting happens when fractions add up to a WHOLE. 3/4 + 1/4 = 4/4. But 4/4 means 4 pieces out of 4 — that is the WHOLE thing! 4/4 = 1. With fraction circles: place 3/4 and 1/4 together — they fill the complete circle. And sometimes the answer is MORE than 1 whole: 3/4 + 3/4 = 6/4. That is 1 whole (4/4) plus 2/4 left over, which equals 1 and 1/2.
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes, when you add fractions, you end up with enough pieces to make a whole pizza! Like if you have 3 slices and add 1 more, you have all 4 slices, which is one whole pizza. Other times, you might end up with *more* than one whole pizza, like 6 slices when a whole pizza only has 4 – we'll learn how to say that in a special way!

slides.text: The RULE is simple: same denominator, add the numerators, keep the denominator. 2/5 + 1/5 = 3/5. 3/8 + 4/8 = 7/8. 5/6 + 4/6 = 9/6 = 1 and 3/6 = 1 and 1/2. The tricky part is when the answer is more than 1 — you need to pull out the whole number. Now let us practice with real-world word problems to see how useful this is!
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's the main rule to remember: when adding fractions with the same bottom number, just add the top numbers and keep the bottom number exactly the same. It's like having 2 apples and getting 1 more apple; you have 3 apples, not 3 *anything else*. We'll practice this rule and also learn how to handle when your answer is bigger than one whole thing.

slides.prompt:
Fraction addition practice:
1. Solve with fraction circles, then write the equation:
   1/3 + 1/3 = | 2/6 + 3/6 = | 1/8 + 5/8 = | 3/4 + 1/4 =
   2/5 + 2/5 = | 4/6 + 5/6 = | 3/8 + 7/8 = | 5/10 + 3/10 =
2. Word problems:
   - You ate 2/8 of a pizza. Your friend ate 3/8. How much was eaten altogether?
   - A recipe needs 1/4 cup of sugar and 2/4 cup of flour. How much total dry ingredient?
   - You read 3/6 of a book on Monday and 2/6 on Tuesday. How much have you read?
3. Create your own fraction addition word problem and solve it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to play with fractions! First, use your fraction circles to build the answers to these problems, and then write down the math sentence. After that, we'll look at some fun stories, like how much pizza was eaten, and you'll even get to make up your own!

slides.text: Adding fractions with the same denominator is straightforward: same size pieces, just count them up. The key is remembering that the denominator tells you the piece SIZE (it does not change when you add) and the numerator tells you HOW MANY pieces. When you get more pieces than make a whole, convert to a mixed number. This skill appears in cooking, measuring, building, and every kind of math you will study in the future.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child add fractions with the same denominator correctly? Do they understand why the denominator stays the same? Can they recognize when a sum equals or exceeds one whole? Can they convert improper fractions to mixed numbers? Can they solve fraction addition word problems?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job adding fractions today! We learned that when the pieces are the same size, you just add up how many you have, and the size of the pieces (the bottom number) stays the same. You even figured out how to handle when you have more than one whole thing, which is super important for cooking and lots of other things!

parent_notes: Adding same-denominator fractions is conceptually the simplest fraction operation, but it establishes patterns critical for later math. The key conceptual point is that the denominator describes the size of pieces (it stays the same) while the numerator counts pieces (it changes). Watch for the common error of adding both numerator AND denominator (1/4 + 2/4 does NOT equal 3/8). The fraction circles make the correct process visible. Problems that result in improper fractions (more than 1 whole) introduce mixed numbers naturally. Real-world word problems ground the abstraction in experience: cooking is especially rich for fraction practice. If your child seems ready, try simple fraction addition while actually baking — measure 1/4 cup, then 2/4 cup, and discuss the total.

title: After the Revolution — Creating a New Government
description: Students explore the challenges America faced after winning independence: governing 13 states with different interests, paying war debts, and the journey from the weak Articles of Confederation to the Constitutional Convention of 1787. They learn how compromise built the framework for American democracy.
instructions:
1. Review: The war is over. America is independent. Now what?
2. The problem: 13 states with different sizes, economies, and interests.
3. First attempt: Articles of Confederation — a very weak central government.
4. Problems with the Articles: could not collect taxes, no national army, no courts.
5. Shays' Rebellion: farmers could not pay debts, the government could not respond.
6. The Constitutional Convention: 55 delegates meet in Philadelphia (1787).
7. Key figures: Washington (presided), Madison ('Father of the Constitution'), Franklin.
8. The Great Compromise: two chambers of Congress (Senate and House).
9. The result: the US Constitution — a framework that still governs us today.
10. Students create a simple timeline from Yorktown to Constitution ratification.

slides.heading: After the Revolution
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is the title of our lesson! It's telling us we're going to learn about what happened *after* America won its freedom in the Revolutionary War, and how the new country started to figure out how to have its own government. Isn't it exciting to think about building something brand new?

items: Images of Constitutional Convention and key figures
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a simple timeline template spanning 1781 (Yorktown) to 1789 (Washington inaugurated) with spaces for students to fill in key events. Have images of Washington, Madison, and Franklin. Create a simple comparison chart of Articles of Confederation vs. Constitution. The key message: building a government through compromise is difficult but essential work.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool things we'll need for our history adventure today! We have a timeline to help us see when things happened, a map to see where the original 13 states were, and pictures of important people. You'll also need your history journal and a pencil to write down what you learn, plus a special paper to make your own timeline. Go find your grown-up helper and gather all these items!

slides.text: Imagine you and your friends just won an impossible battle. You are free! But now comes an even harder question: HOW do you all live together? The 13 states were like 13 separate countries — they had different sizes, different economies, different ideas about government. Virginia was huge; Rhode Island was tiny. Some states had slavery; others did not. Getting them to agree on ANYTHING was enormously difficult.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is like imagining a big game where you and your friends just won! You're all super excited to be free, but then you have to figure out how to play together fairly. The 13 states were a lot like that – they were all used to doing their own thing and had different ideas, so getting them to agree on rules for everyone was super tricky.

slides.text: Their first try was the ARTICLES OF CONFEDERATION — basically a friendship agreement between 13 independent states. The central government was very weak on purpose (they had just fought a king and did not want another powerful ruler). But too weak was also a problem: the government could not collect taxes, could not raise an army, and could not settle disagreements between states. It was like a team with no captain.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, after winning their freedom, the states tried making a "friendship agreement" called the Articles of Confederation. They made the main government really weak because they were scared of having a powerful leader like a king again. But, it turned out to be *too* weak, like a team with no captain, because it couldn't even collect money or have a strong army.

slides.text: Things got so bad that when farmers in Massachusetts could not pay their debts and rebelled (SHAYS' REBELLION), the national government could not even respond. Leaders realized the Articles were not working. In May 1787, 55 delegates gathered in Philadelphia to fix the problem. George Washington led the meeting. James Madison came with detailed plans. Benjamin Franklin, now 81 years old, brought wisdom and humor.
slides.mascot_explanation: Things got so tricky with that weak government that when some farmers were in trouble and protested, the government couldn't even help stop it! This showed everyone that the Articles of Confederation just weren't working. So, in 1787, lots of important people, like George Washington and James Madison, got together in Philadelphia to try and fix things.

slides.text: The delegates argued all summer. Big states wanted representation based on population. Small states wanted equal representation. The solution? The GREAT COMPROMISE: TWO chambers of Congress — the House of Representatives (based on population, so big states have more voice) and the Senate (two per state, so small states are equally heard). Through COMPROMISE, they created the US CONSTITUTION — the document that STILL governs America today, over 230 years later.
slides.mascot_explanation: All summer long, these leaders talked and debated, trying to figure out how to make a government that worked for both big states and small states. They finally came up with a super smart idea called the Great Compromise, which created two parts for Congress: one where states are represented by how many people they have, and another where every state gets the same number of votes. This compromise helped them create the US Constitution, which is still the rulebook for our country today!

slides.prompt:
Two activities:
1. Create a timeline from 1781 to 1789 with these events:
   - 1781: Yorktown surrender
   - 1783: Treaty of Paris
   - 1781-1787: Articles of Confederation period
   - 1786-87: Shays' Rebellion
   - 1787: Constitutional Convention
   - 1788: Constitution ratified
   - 1789: Washington inaugurated as first President
2. In your history journal, write a paragraph answering: Why was it so hard for 13 states to agree on one government? Give at least 3 reasons.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a history detective! First, you'll create a timeline showing the important moments from when the war ended to when our country got its new government. Then, in your journal, write down why you think it was so hard for those 13 states to agree on how to run things together. You've got this!

slides.text: Building a government is harder than winning a war. The Founders had to find ways for people who disagreed about almost everything to work together. The Constitution was not perfect — it did not end slavery, it did not include women's rights — but it created a framework that could be AMENDED (changed and improved) over time. The art of COMPROMISE — finding solutions where everyone gives a little — is one of the most important skills in democracy and in life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why the Articles of Confederation failed? Can they describe the Constitutional Convention and at least 2 key figures? Do they understand the Great Compromise? Can they explain why compromise was necessary? Can they sequence events from Yorktown to the Constitution?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned that building a country is way harder than winning a war, and that people who disagree can still find ways to work together. The most amazing thing is that even though the first plan wasn't perfect, the Founders created a way to change and improve it over time, which is what compromise is all about!

parent_notes: This lesson bridges the Revolution unit with the foundations of American government. The concept of compromise is central and applies directly to children's social lives — finding solutions where everyone gives a little is a skill they use on the playground and at home. The Articles of Confederation provide an important lesson about balance: too little government creates chaos, too much creates tyranny. The Founders were trying to find the middle ground. The Constitution is presented honestly — as a remarkable achievement that was also deeply flawed (slavery, women's exclusion). These imperfections are important to acknowledge because they show that democracy is an ongoing project of improvement. If your child is interested, the story of the Constitutional Convention — the secret sessions, the fierce debates, Franklin's witticisms — reads like a political thriller.

title: Southeast Region — History and Culture
description: Students explore the rich history and diverse culture of the US Southeast region, from Native American civilizations through the Civil War and civil rights movement, to the region's distinctive music, food, and traditions that have shaped American culture.
instructions:
1. Review Southeast states and physical features from Day 1.
2. Native American history: Cherokee, Chickasaw, Choctaw, Creek, Seminole — the Five Civilized Tribes.
3. Colonial history: Jamestown (1607), plantation economy, slavery.
4. The Civil War: the Southeast was the heart of the Confederacy.
5. Civil rights movement: Montgomery bus boycott, sit-ins, marches.
6. Cultural contributions: jazz and blues (New Orleans), country music (Nashville), bluegrass.
7. Food traditions: barbecue, Cajun and Creole cooking, sweet tea, pecan pie.
8. Students create a cultural map of the Southeast.
9. Write about one cultural contribution that interests them most.
10. Discuss: How has the Southeast shaped American culture?

slides.heading: Southeast Culture
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into the Southeast! It tells us we're going to learn all about the special history, music, and traditions that make this part of America so unique. Think of it as the cover of a really cool book we're about to read together!

items: Images of historic sites and cultural landmarks
Audio samples of jazz, blues, and country music
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a map for cultural annotations. Gather images of key sites: Jamestown, Civil War battlefields, Montgomery, Nashville. If possible, have short audio clips of jazz (Louis Armstrong), blues (B.B. King), and country music. Have information about Southern food traditions and cultural practices ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our Southeast exploration! We've got a map to draw on, pictures of famous places like old settlements and music cities, a notebook and pencil for writing down our thoughts, colorful pencils to make our map amazing, and even some music clips to listen to. Make sure you have a grown-up help you gather all these things so we're ready to go!

slides.text: The Southeast has one of the richest and most complex histories of any American region. For thousands of years, powerful Native American nations thrived here — the Cherokee, Chickasaw, Choctaw, Creek, and Seminole, known as the Five Civilized Tribes. They had governments, farms, written languages, and thriving communities long before Europeans arrived.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is like stepping way, way back in time! It's telling us that long before anyone else lived here, powerful Native American groups called the Cherokee, Chickasaw, Choctaw, Creek, and Seminole were already thriving. They had their own ways of living, farming, and even writing, which is super impressive!

slides.text: European colonization changed everything. The first permanent English settlement, Jamestown, was established in Virginia in 1607. As plantations grew, the tragic institution of SLAVERY became central to the Southern economy. Millions of enslaved Africans were forced to work the fields. This painful history led to the Civil War (1861-1865) and, a century later, to the civil rights movement that fought for equality and justice.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're learning about when people from Europe started arriving. The very first English town, called Jamestown, was built way back in 1607. As more people came, big farms called plantations started, and sadly, many people were forced into slavery, which is a very important and difficult part of history. This led to big disagreements, like the Civil War, and later, a big fight for fairness called the civil rights movement.

slides.text: From this complex history came extraordinary CULTURE. Jazz was born in New Orleans — a blend of African rhythms, European harmonies, and American creativity. The blues grew from the songs of enslaved people in the Mississippi Delta. Nashville became the home of country music. Southern FOOD is famous worldwide: barbecue slow-smoked over wood, Cajun and Creole dishes from Louisiana, sweet cornbread, peach cobbler, and sweet tea.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, even though the history is complicated, the Southeast gave us some amazing culture! Think about music like jazz, which started in New Orleans with its lively rhythms, and the blues, which came from the songs of people working hard. Nashville is famous for country music, and don't forget the yummy food like barbecue and sweet tea!

slides.text: The Southeast also gave America some of its most important heroes: Martin Luther King Jr., Rosa Parks, Ruby Bridges, and many others who fought for civil rights. Today the Southeast blends its traditions with modern growth — cities like Atlanta, Charlotte, and Nashville are among the fastest-growing in America. The region's history is complicated, but its contributions to American culture are immeasurable.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide highlights some of the bravest people who fought for what's right, like Martin Luther King Jr. and Rosa Parks, who worked hard to make things fair for everyone. The Southeast is also growing super fast with big, busy cities, but it always remembers its special traditions and history, even when things change.

slides.prompt:
Create a cultural map of the Southeast:
1. Mark historic sites: Jamestown (VA), Charleston (SC), Montgomery (AL), Nashville (TN), New Orleans (LA)
2. Add cultural labels: Jazz music near New Orleans, Country music near Nashville, Civil rights sites in Alabama
3. Add food regions: Cajun cooking in Louisiana, Barbecue across the region
4. In your journal, write a paragraph about ONE cultural contribution from the Southeast that interests you most. Why does it interest you?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to make our own masterpiece! We're going to take our map and mark important places like where Jamestown was, and cities where jazz and country music are famous, and places where the civil rights movement happened. Then, in your journal, pick one thing that really caught your eye – maybe the music, the food, or a historical event – and write a few sentences about why you think it's so interesting!

slides.text: The Southeast region has shaped American culture in profound ways — through music, food, history, and the ongoing struggle for justice and equality. Understanding this region means understanding America itself: its beauty and its contradictions, its creativity and its challenges, its past and its future.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 3 cultural contributions of the Southeast? Can they explain the significance of the civil rights movement? Can they identify at least 3 historic sites? Do they understand how history shaped the region's culture?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We explored the Southeast and saw how its history, music, and food have made America what it is today. You learned about important music styles, delicious foods, and big moments in history, like the fight for civil rights. It's amazing how one region can have such a huge impact on a whole country!

parent_notes: The Southeast's history includes both inspiring achievements and painful injustices. Present both honestly and age-appropriately. Children at this age have a strong sense of fairness and can process the concept that people were treated unjustly and that brave individuals worked to change that. The music connection is powerful — play actual recordings if possible. Southern food traditions often have deep cultural roots: barbecue techniques came from both Native American and African traditions, Cajun cooking reflects French, African, and Native American influences. If your family has Southern heritage, share your stories. If not, explore a Southern recipe together. The cultural map activity helps children see how geography and history create unique regional identities.

title: Read Aloud — Shiloh, Chapters 11-13
description: Students continue reading Shiloh, reaching the climactic chapters where Marty's secret is exposed and he must face the consequences. They explore themes of honesty, courage, standing up for what is right, and the difference between legal ownership and moral responsibility.
instructions:
1. Review chapters 8-10: What happened? How was Marty feeling?
2. Read chapter 11 aloud — the crisis point approaches.
3. Pause for predictions: What will happen when the truth comes out?
4. Read chapter 12 — major events unfold.
5. Discuss: How do different characters react? Why?
6. Read chapter 13 — Marty takes action.
7. Character analysis: How does Marty show courage?
8. Theme discussion: ownership vs. responsibility — who SHOULD have Shiloh?
9. Students write a response: Was Marty right in what he did?
10. Vocabulary and reading comprehension questions.

slides.heading: Shiloh
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a book, showing us the title, "Shiloh," and telling us we're going to read chapters 11, 12, and 13, which are all about when Marty's secret gets out and he has to deal with the results.

slides.setup_instructions: These are pivotal chapters. Read ahead to prepare for emotional moments. Have tissues available — this part of the story is intense. Prepare discussion questions that let children process the moral complexity without dictating what they should feel. Update the character traits chart with space for new developments.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us everything we'll need for our reading adventure today! We have the book "Shiloh," our special reading journals to write in, a pencil for writing, a chart to keep track of what characters are like, and some vocabulary cards with new words. The grown-up helper also says to have tissues ready because these chapters can be a little sad or intense, and we'll be updating our character chart with new things we learn about them.

slides.text: We have been following Marty as he hides Shiloh and struggles with the lies he has to tell. The tension has been building chapter by chapter. Today we reach the critical turning point — the moment when secrets come to light and Marty must face what he has done. Let us see how our characters respond when truth arrives.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is telling us that we've been reading about Marty hiding Shiloh and all the tricky things he's had to do, and now we're getting to the really important part where the truth is going to come out. It's like when you've been holding a secret for a long time, and finally, everyone finds out what's going on. We're going to pay close attention to how everyone acts when Marty's secret is revealed.

slides.text: [Read chapters 11-12 aloud with appropriate pacing and emotion.] These chapters change everything. Notice how the author has been building to this moment — every choice Marty made, every lie he told, every risk he took leads to this point. How do the different characters react? Marty's father? His mother? Think about WHY each person responds the way they do.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready, because this is where we read chapters 11 and 12, and the story is going to change a lot! As we listen, try to notice how the author built up all these moments, leading to this big reveal, and think about how Marty's dad, mom, and other characters react to everything. It's important to think about *why* they react in certain ways, just like in real life when people have different feelings about the same thing.

slides.text: [Read chapter 13 aloud.] Marty shows a different kind of courage now — not the secret courage of hiding, but the open courage of STANDING UP for what he believes is right, even when it means facing consequences. This is harder than hiding. It means being honest, accepting responsibility, and still fighting for Shiloh.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read chapter 13, and this is where Marty shows a different kind of bravery! It's not just about being brave when no one is looking, but about being brave enough to stand up for what he believes is right, even if it means getting in trouble. This is super hard because it means being honest and taking responsibility for his actions, but he's still trying his best to protect Shiloh.

slides.text: Here is the big question: Judd Travers LEGALLY owns Shiloh. He bought the dog with his own money. But Judd abuses the dog, and Marty loves and cares for Shiloh. Who SHOULD have the dog? This is the difference between LEGAL ownership and MORAL responsibility. Sometimes the law says one thing, but our hearts say another. There is no easy answer — that is what makes this a great book.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is asking a really big question: Judd legally owns Shiloh because he bought him, but Judd isn't a good owner and Marty loves Shiloh and takes care of him. So, who *should* have Shiloh? This is where we think about the difference between what the law says and what feels right in our hearts, and sometimes those two things don't match up, which can be tricky but makes for a really interesting story.

slides.prompt:
In your reading journal:
1. Summarize the key events of chapters 11-13 (6-8 sentences)
2. Update your character traits chart — how have characters changed?
3. Write a full paragraph answering: Who should have Shiloh — Judd or Marty? Support your opinion with at least 3 reasons
4. Prediction: How do you think the book will end? Why?
5. Vocabulary: Define 3 new words and use each in a sentence
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to do some super important work in your reading journal! First, you'll write down the main things that happened in chapters 11, 12, and 13 in your own words. Then, you'll update your character chart to show how the people in the story have changed. After that, you'll write a whole paragraph explaining who you think should have Shiloh, giving at least three reasons why, and finish by guessing how the book might end and why.

slides.text: Shiloh teaches us that doing the right thing is not always simple or easy. Marty had to lie to protect an animal from abuse, and those lies created their own problems. Now he faces the truth and must find a new way forward. The question of legal ownership vs. moral responsibility appears throughout life — in big issues and small ones. What matters is that we THINK about these questions carefully and act with both courage and compassion.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child summarize the key events of chapters 11-13? Can they analyze character motivations and reactions? Can they articulate the legal vs. moral ownership dilemma? Can they form and defend an opinion with textual evidence?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is reminding us that doing the right thing isn't always easy, like how Marty had to lie to protect Shiloh but that caused other problems. Now he's facing the truth and trying to figure out what to do next, which teaches us about how sometimes things aren't just black and white. It’s important to think hard about these kinds of tricky situations and try to be brave and kind when we make choices.

parent_notes: These climactic chapters may provoke strong emotions. Children who have bonded with Shiloh through the reading may feel anxious, angry, or sad. These feelings are appropriate and valuable — literature that moves us teaches empathy and moral reasoning. Help your child process their feelings by talking about the characters and situations rather than minimizing emotions ('It is just a story'). The legal vs. moral ownership question has no right answer, which is exactly the point. Support your child in forming their OWN opinion and defending it with reasoning. This builds critical thinking and moral development simultaneously. Phyllis Reynolds Naylor wrote sequels (Shiloh Season and Saving Shiloh) if your child wants to continue with these characters.

title: Oral Presentation Skills — Practice and Peer Feedback
description: Students do a full rehearsal of their presentations, combining their content plan, delivery skills, and visual aids. They present to small groups, receive structured peer feedback, and make final adjustments before presentation day.
instructions:
1. Review all presentation components: plan, delivery, visual aid.
2. Set expectations: today is a PRACTICE run — it is okay to make mistakes.
3. Organize small groups of 3-4 students.
4. Each student presents to their small group (2-3 minutes each).
5. Audience members fill out feedback forms: strengths and one suggestion.
6. After each presentation, the group discusses what worked well.
7. Students read their feedback and identify one thing to improve.
8. Second round: students present again with improvements.
9. Compare: How was the second time different from the first?
10. Final preparations: make any last adjustments to plan, visual, or delivery.

slides.heading: Practice Presentations
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our big practice session today! It tells us we're going to be working on our presentation skills by practicing and getting helpful ideas from our friends. Think of it like getting ready for a big game or a concert – practice makes perfect!

slides.setup_instructions: Arrange the room into small group stations with 3-4 chairs facing a standing area. Prepare peer feedback forms with: Speaker Name, Topic, What They Did Well (2 things), One Suggestion for Improvement, and a rating scale for Volume, Eye Contact, Organization, and Visual Aid. Set the timer for 2-3 minutes per presentation. Create a supportive atmosphere — this is practice, not performance.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we need for our practice. We’ve got our presentation plans, our awesome visual aids we made, and little index cards to help us remember what to say. We also need a timer to keep us on track, special forms to write down feedback for our friends, and a pencil. Make sure you have all these ready to go before we start our groups!

slides.text: Today is REHEARSAL DAY — your chance to practice your full presentation and get feedback before the real thing. Athletes practice before the game. Musicians rehearse before the concert. Speakers practice before the speech. The more you practice, the more confident you will feel. Today you will present TWICE — once to get feedback, and once to use that feedback.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like the starting signal for our practice! Today is all about rehearsal, which is just a fancy word for practicing. Just like athletes practice before a big game, we’re practicing our presentations so we can feel super confident when it’s time for the real thing. We’ll even get to practice twice to see how much we can improve!

slides.text: When you are the PRESENTER: Stand up, take a breath, and begin with your hook. Use your index cards for reference but try to look UP at your audience as much as possible. Use your visual aid at the right moment. Speak clearly and at a good pace. End with your closing and say 'Thank you.' It is OKAY to make mistakes — that is why we practice!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let’s talk about what to do when it’s YOUR turn to present. When you stand up, take a deep breath, start with your exciting hook, and try to look at your friends as you talk. Remember to use your visual aid at the right time and speak clearly. Don't worry about making mistakes, because that’s exactly why we practice!

slides.text: When you are the AUDIENCE: Your job is just as important! Sit quietly, look at the speaker, and LISTEN. After they finish, fill out the feedback form. Be HONEST but KIND. Start with what they did WELL — everyone needs to hear what is working. Then give ONE specific suggestion: 'Maybe speak a little louder' is helpful. 'It was bad' is NOT helpful.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is for everyone who is listening while their friend is presenting. Your job is super important too! Sit nicely, pay attention, and really listen to what your friend is saying. After they finish, you'll fill out a feedback form to tell them what they did well and give them one helpful idea for improvement, like maybe speaking a little louder.

slides.text: After Round 1, read your feedback carefully. Choose ONE thing to focus on improving. You cannot fix everything at once, so pick the most important suggestion. Then present AGAIN in Round 2. Notice how much better the second time feels — even small improvements make a big difference. This is how professionals get better: practice, feedback, adjust, practice again.
slides.mascot_explanation: After our first round of practice presentations, we’ll look at the feedback our friends gave us. The most important thing to do is pick just ONE suggestion to work on. You can't fix everything at once, so focus on that one thing, and then we’ll present again! You’ll be amazed at how much better you’ll feel the second time.

slides.prompt:
Presentation Practice:
Round 1 (15 min): Each student presents to their small group (2-3 min each). Audience fills out feedback forms after each presentation.
Feedback Review (3 min): Read your feedback. Circle ONE thing to improve.
Round 2 (15 min): Present again with your improvement. Audience notices what changed.
Reflection: In your notebook, answer: What improved from Round 1 to Round 2? What will you practice before presentation day?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the magic happens – our actual presentation practice! We’ll take turns presenting to our small groups for a few minutes each, and then we’ll fill out those feedback forms. After that, we’ll read our feedback, pick one thing to improve, and present *again* to see how much we’ve changed! Finally, we’ll jot down in our notebooks what we improved and what we’ll keep practicing.

slides.text: You just experienced the most powerful learning cycle there is: TRY, GET FEEDBACK, IMPROVE, TRY AGAIN. Professional speakers, athletes, and artists all use this cycle. Notice how much better your second presentation was compared to your first — that improvement came from just ONE round of feedback and practice. Imagine how good you will be by presentation day! Keep practicing at home.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child deliver a complete 2-3 minute presentation with hook, body, and closing? Do they use appropriate voice, posture, and eye contact? Can they integrate their visual aid effectively? Can they give constructive peer feedback? Can they identify and implement improvements based on feedback?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we just finished our practice, and you did an amazing job! You learned how to try something, get helpful ideas from others, and then try it again even better. This is how real pros get better at anything, and you totally rocked it today. Keep practicing what you learned, and you'll be absolutely fantastic on presentation day!

parent_notes: The practice-feedback-improve cycle is one of the most valuable learning experiences in education. By presenting twice, children see immediate improvement, which builds confidence and motivation. The peer feedback component teaches both giving and receiving constructive criticism — skills essential for life. At home, be an enthusiastic practice audience. Ask your child to present to family members, stuffed animals, or even the mirror. Each repetition reduces anxiety and improves fluency. If your child is nervous, normalize the feeling: 'Everyone gets nervous, even professional speakers. Nervousness means you care about doing well.' Focus praise on specific behaviors ('I loved how you looked right at me when you said that') rather than general statements ('Good job').

title: Fractions Review — Subtracting Fractions and Mixed Practice
description: Students review subtracting fractions with the same denominator and then engage in mixed practice combining all fraction skills: naming, comparing, adding, and subtracting. This comprehensive review solidifies fraction understanding through varied problem types and real-world applications.
instructions:
1. Connect to addition: if adding fractions means combining pieces, subtracting means taking away.
2. Same denominator subtraction: subtract the numerators, keep the denominator.
3. Demonstrate: 5/8 - 2/8 = 3/8 — show with fraction circles.
4. Subtracting from a whole: 1 - 3/4 = 4/4 - 3/4 = 1/4.
5. Practice 6 subtraction problems with manipulatives.
6. Mixed practice: naming, comparing, adding, and subtracting fractions.
7. Real-world problem set: cooking, measuring, sharing scenarios.
8. Fraction review game: spin the spinner, perform the operation.
9. Students self-assess: what fraction skills are strong? What needs more practice?
10. Preview: these skills prepare you for multiplying fractions next year!

slides.heading: Fraction Subtraction and Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey there! This first slide is like the title page for our adventure today. It's telling us we're going to be working with fractions, specifically subtracting them, and then putting all our fraction smarts together to solve all sorts of problems. Think of it as our mission briefing for becoming fraction experts!

items: Spinner labeled: Name It, Compare, Add, Subtract
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a mixed practice worksheet with 20 problems covering all four fraction skills in random order. Create a spinner with four sections: Name It (identify a fraction from a picture), Compare (use > < =), Add (same denominator), Subtract (same denominator). Have fraction circles accessible for all problems. Include a self-assessment checklist at the end.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us all the cool tools we'll need for our fraction mission! We've got fraction circles, which are like pizza slices but for math – they help us see the pieces. We also have a number line, a notebook, a pencil, a worksheet with mixed problems, and a spinner that will tell us what kind of fraction puzzle to solve next. Go grab all these things so we're ready to go!

slides.text: Subtracting fractions with the same denominator is just like adding, but in reverse. Instead of combining pieces, you TAKE AWAY pieces. 5/8 minus 2/8: you have 5 eighth-pieces and take away 2 of them. 5 minus 2 equals 3, so you have 3/8 left. The denominator stays the same because the SIZE of the pieces has not changed.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important step for learning how to subtract fractions. Remember how adding fractions is like putting pieces together? Well, subtracting is the opposite – it's like taking pieces away! So, if we have 5/8 of something and we take away 2/8, we just count how many pieces are left, and the size of the pieces (the denominator, 8) stays the same. It's like eating 2 slices of an 8-slice pizza – you started with 5 slices and ate 2, so you have 3 slices left!

slides.text: A special case: subtracting from a WHOLE number. What is 1 minus 3/4? First, convert 1 to a fraction with the same denominator: 1 = 4/4. Now: 4/4 minus 3/4 = 1/4. See it with fraction circles: start with a whole circle, take away the 3/4 piece, and 1/4 remains. This works for any whole number: 2 - 5/6 = 12/6 - 5/6 = 7/6 = 1 and 1/6.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step shows us a neat trick for when we need to subtract a fraction from a whole number, like 1 whole pizza. To do it, we first pretend the '1' is a fraction with the same bottom number as the other fraction. So, if we're taking away 3/4, we change the '1' into '4/4' so we can easily subtract the pieces and see that only 1/4 is left. It’s like having a whole pizza and giving away 3 slices – you’d have 1 slice left!

slides.text: Now let us put ALL our fraction skills together! This week we reviewed: NAMING fractions (numerator and denominator), COMPARING fractions (same denominator or same numerator), ADDING fractions (same denominator, add numerators), and now SUBTRACTING fractions (same denominator, subtract numerators). You have a complete fraction toolkit!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This slide is reminding us of all the amazing fraction skills we've learned. We can name fractions, compare them to see which is bigger, add them together, and now we know how to subtract them too! Think of it like having a whole toolbox filled with different tools, and each tool helps us solve a different kind of fraction puzzle.

slides.text: Fractions are not just math class problems — they are EVERYWHERE. When you follow a recipe and measure 3/4 cup of flour, that is fractions. When you eat 2 slices of an 8-slice pizza, you ate 2/8 or 1/4. When a song plays for 3 and 1/2 minutes, that is a fraction. When you have read 5/6 of your book, that is a fraction. The better you understand fractions, the better you understand the world.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us that fractions aren't just for math class – they're all around us in real life! When you're baking and measure ingredients, or when you share a pizza, or even when you look at how much of your book you've read, you're using fractions. Understanding fractions helps you understand how things are divided and shared in the world.

slides.prompt:
Mixed Fraction Practice:
1. Subtraction problems (use fraction circles):
   5/6 - 2/6 = | 7/8 - 3/8 = | 4/5 - 1/5 = | 1 - 2/3 = | 1 - 5/8 = | 3/4 - 1/4 =
2. Mixed Practice Worksheet (20 problems): naming, comparing, adding, and subtracting fractions in random order
3. Spinner Game: Spin to determine the operation, then solve the fraction problem
4. Self-Assessment: Rate yourself 1-5 on each skill: Naming, Comparing, Adding, Subtracting. What is your strongest skill? What needs more practice?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time for the fun part – putting all our fraction skills to the test! First, we'll do some subtraction problems using our fraction circles to help us see the pieces. Then, we'll tackle a worksheet with all sorts of fraction problems, like naming, comparing, adding, and subtracting. After that, we'll spin the spinner to pick a challenge! Lastly, we'll think about which fraction skills are super easy for us now and which ones we might want to practice a little more.

slides.text: You now have a complete set of fraction skills! You can NAME fractions, COMPARE them, ADD them, and SUBTRACT them. These are the building blocks for everything you will learn about fractions in the future — multiplying, dividing, and working with different denominators. Be proud of how far you have come. Fractions are one of the most important topics in all of mathematics, and you have a solid foundation.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child subtract fractions with the same denominator? Can they subtract a fraction from a whole number? Can they perform all four fraction operations (name, compare, add, subtract) correctly? Can they apply fraction skills to word problems? Can they self-assess their strengths and areas for growth?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! We've gone through all the steps and practiced so many different fraction skills today. You can now name, compare, add, and subtract fractions, and even subtract them from a whole number! These skills are like superpowers that will help you with even more exciting math later on, like multiplying fractions. Give yourself a big pat on the back for becoming such a fantastic fraction whiz!

parent_notes: This mixed review is designed to consolidate all fraction learning from the week. The variety of problem types prevents rote memorization and requires children to think about what each problem is asking. The self-assessment component builds metacognition — awareness of one's own learning. If your child identifies a weak area, do extra practice in that specific skill rather than reviewing everything equally. The spinner game makes practice feel like play rather than drill. Real-world connections (cooking, pizza, measuring) help children see fractions as useful tools rather than abstract concepts. Consider doing some fraction cooking at home: recipes that call for halves, thirds, and fourths provide hands-on fraction practice that results in something delicious.

title: Healthy Habits — Hygiene, Handwashing, and Germ Prevention
description: Students learn about germs — bacteria and viruses — how they spread, and how simple hygiene habits prevent illness. They conduct a hands-on experiment demonstrating how germs transfer between surfaces and learn the proper handwashing technique recommended by health professionals.
instructions:
1. Connect to nutrition and sleep lessons: another pillar of health is CLEANLINESS.
2. What are germs? Tiny living things (bacteria) and particles (viruses) that can make us sick.
3. How germs spread: coughing, sneezing, touching surfaces, sharing food/drinks.
4. The glitter experiment: put glitter on hands, shake hands, touch surfaces — see how it spreads.
5. Handwashing: the #1 way to prevent illness. 20 seconds with soap and water.
6. Demonstrate proper technique: wet, soap, scrub (palms, backs, between fingers, under nails), rinse, dry.
7. When to wash: before eating, after bathroom, after sneezing/coughing, after playing outside.
8. Other hygiene habits: brushing teeth, bathing, clean clothes, covering coughs.
9. Students practice proper handwashing technique.
10. Create a 'Germ Prevention' poster for the classroom or home.

slides.heading: Germ Prevention
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our big adventure into staying healthy! It's called "Germ Prevention," and we're going to learn all about how to keep yucky germs away from our bodies so we can feel our best. It's super important because it helps us understand how to be strong and not get sick!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a handwashing station with soap, water, and paper towels. Have fine glitter ready for the germ-spreading demonstration. Prepare images or diagrams of bacteria and viruses at a child-friendly level. Have poster materials ready for the prevention poster activity. The glitter experiment is messy but memorable — lay down newspaper or do it outside.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our germ-fighting mission! We've got glitter, which is going to pretend to be germs so we can see how they move around. We'll also need soap and water to wash those pretend germs away, and paper towels to dry our super clean hands. Get all these things ready, and maybe put down some newspaper for the glitter, just in case!

slides.text: GERMS are tiny living things so small you cannot see them without a microscope. There are two main types: BACTERIA (tiny one-celled organisms) and VIRUSES (even tinier particles that invade your cells). Most bacteria are actually harmless or even helpful — the bacteria in your gut help you digest food! But some germs cause illness: colds, flu, stomach bugs, and infections. The question is: HOW do germs get from one person to another?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we meet the tiny troublemakers: germs! Germs are super, super small living things, like bacteria, and even smaller particles called viruses, that can sometimes make us feel yucky like when we have a cold. While some germs are actually good for us, like the ones that help us eat our food, others can cause sickness, and it's good to know how they travel from place to place.

slides.text: Germs spread in several ways. When you COUGH or SNEEZE, tiny droplets fly through the air carrying germs. When you TOUCH a surface (doorknob, table, phone) that a sick person touched, germs transfer to your hands. When you then TOUCH YOUR FACE (eyes, nose, mouth), the germs enter your body. This is called the CHAIN OF INFECTION. Let us see it in action with our glitter experiment!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to see how those tiny germs get around! Germs love to jump from person to person when we cough or sneeze, or when we touch things like doorknobs or toys that someone else has touched. If we then touch our eyes, nose, or mouth with germy hands, those germs can get inside our bodies and make us sick. It's like a germy game of tag, and we're going to see how it works with our glitter experiment!

slides.text: [Glitter experiment.] The glitter on your hands represents germs. Now shake hands with a partner — look, the glitter transferred! Touch the table — glitter on the table. Touch your face — glitter on your face. This is EXACTLY how germs spread. Now, what BREAKS the chain? HANDWASHING! Wash your hands with soap for 20 seconds and watch the glitter disappear. Soap breaks apart germ cells and water washes them away.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that glitter spreading everywhere! This is just like how germs travel when we shake hands or touch things. But guess what breaks the germ chain? Washing our hands with soap and water for 20 seconds! See how the soap lifts the glitter off your hands and the water washes it all away? That’s exactly what happens with real germs, and it’s the best way to stop them!

slides.text: Proper handwashing takes 20 SECONDS — sing 'Happy Birthday' twice. The technique: WET hands, add SOAP, then SCRUB everywhere: palms, backs of hands, between fingers, under fingernails, and wrists. RINSE under running water and DRY with a clean towel. Other hygiene habits matter too: brush teeth twice daily, bathe regularly, wear clean clothes, cover coughs with your elbow (not your hand!), and never share drinks or utensils with someone who is sick.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is our super-secret handshake for beating germs: proper handwashing! It takes 20 seconds, about the time it takes to sing "Happy Birthday" twice. Remember to get your hands wet, add soap, and scrub *everywhere* – your palms, the backs of your hands, between your fingers, and even under your nails. Then rinse them clean and dry them off. Doing this often, especially before eating and after using the bathroom, is a superhero move for your health!

slides.prompt:
Three activities:
1. Glitter Germ Experiment: See how 'germs' spread from hands to surfaces to faces. Then wash thoroughly and observe how soap removes them.
2. Proper Handwashing Practice: Time yourself for 20 seconds. Did you scrub palms, backs, between fingers, and under nails?
3. Create a 'Germ Prevention' Poster: Include at least 5 hygiene tips with illustrations. Make it colorful and clear enough to hang in a bathroom or kitchen as a reminder.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to put on our germ-fighting superhero capes! First, we'll do the glitter experiment to see how germs spread and then watch them disappear when we wash our hands. Then, we'll practice washing our hands for a full 20 seconds, making sure we scrub every part. Finally, we get to be artists and create a colorful poster with at least five ways to stop germs, so everyone remembers how to stay healthy!

slides.text: You cannot see germs, but they are everywhere — on every surface you touch, in every sneeze, on every doorknob. The GOOD NEWS is that simple habits protect you: wash your hands properly and often, cover your coughs, keep your body clean, and avoid touching your face with unwashed hands. These habits are the easiest and most effective way to stay healthy. You are now a germ-prevention expert!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what germs are and how they spread? Can they demonstrate proper 20-second handwashing technique? Can they list at least 5 times when handwashing is important? Can they describe at least 3 other hygiene habits that prevent illness?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You're officially a germ-prevention expert! We learned that even though we can't see them, germs are everywhere, but we have super simple ways to protect ourselves. By washing our hands really well, covering our coughs, and keeping ourselves clean, we can stop those germs in their tracks and stay healthy and strong. Keep practicing these habits, and you'll be a germ-fighting champion!

parent_notes: The glitter experiment is one of the most memorable science demonstrations for children — they will think about it every time they touch a doorknob. The 20-second handwashing rule comes from the CDC and WHO, and singing 'Happy Birthday' twice is the child-friendly timer. Research shows that proper handwashing reduces respiratory illness by 21% and gastrointestinal illness by 31%. Make handwashing a non-negotiable habit at home: before meals, after bathroom, after coming inside. The germ prevention poster can be hung in the bathroom as a visual reminder. Avoid creating germ anxiety — the message should be empowering (you can PROTECT yourself) rather than frightening (germs are everywhere and dangerous). Most germs are harmless, and our immune system handles the rest when we support it with good habits.

title: Music — Song Writing Workshop Part 2
description: Students refine the songs they began in Part 1, adding a second verse, practicing melody, and preparing to perform their songs for the class. They learn about musical expression — how dynamics, tempo, and feeling transform lyrics into a real song.
instructions:
1. Review verse-chorus structure from Part 1.
2. Share: read your verse and chorus aloud — how does it sound?
3. Write a SECOND verse: same melody, different words, new detail about your topic.
4. Musical expression: DYNAMICS (loud vs. soft), TEMPO (fast vs. slow), FEELING.
5. Practice singing your complete song: verse 1, chorus, verse 2, chorus.
6. Add dynamics: which parts should be louder? Softer? Why?
7. Add expression: does your song sound happy? Sad? Excited? Match the feeling to the topic.
8. Small group sharing: sing for 2-3 classmates.
9. Peer feedback: what did you enjoy? What feeling did the song give you?
10. Final rehearsal before class performance.

slides.heading: Song Writing Workshop
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our music book! It tells us that we're going to be working on our songs again, making them even better, and getting ready to share them with everyone. We're going to become super songwriters!

items: Audio player for familiar melody reference
Simple percussion instruments if available (tambourine, shaker, drum)
slides.setup_instructions: Have students retrieve their lyrics from Part 1. Set up a small performance area. If percussion instruments are available, set them aside for optional accompaniment. Play the familiar melody they are using as a reference. Create a supportive atmosphere where sharing creative work feels safe and exciting rather than scary.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at this list! We need the song lyrics you already wrote, some paper and a pencil for new ideas, something to play a familiar tune on so we can match our words, and maybe some fun rhythm makers like a tambourine. We'll also need a special spot to practice performing, so let's get everything ready to make some awesome music!

slides.text: Last time you wrote a verse and we created a chorus together. Today you will add a SECOND verse and turn your song into a complete performance. A second verse uses the SAME melody as the first verse but tells a DIFFERENT part of the story. Think of what else you want to say about your topic — a new detail, a new feeling, a new image.
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we wrote one verse and then a chorus last time? Well, today we're going to add a *second* verse! It will use the same tune as the first verse, but we'll put in new words to tell more about our topic, like adding a new picture to our story.

slides.text: Now let us add EXPRESSION. Dynamics means how LOUD or SOFT you sing. A gentle part of the song might be soft; an exciting part might be loud. Tempo means how FAST or SLOW. A happy part might be faster; a thoughtful part might be slower. And FEELING — does your song sound the way it SHOULD for its topic? A song about friendship should sound warm. A song about adventure should sound exciting.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to make our songs sound super interesting! We'll learn about singing loud or soft, called dynamics, and singing fast or slow, called tempo. We'll also think about the feeling of our song – should it sound happy, sad, or super excited?

slides.text: Your complete song structure is: Verse 1, Chorus, Verse 2, Chorus. Some songwriters add a third verse or change the chorus slightly at the end. The important thing is that it FLOWS — one part leads naturally to the next. Practice singing it all the way through. If a line does not fit the melody, change a word or two until it does. Songwriters revise constantly — that is part of the creative process.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us the order of our whole song: first verse, then the chorus, then our brand new second verse, and then the chorus again. It's like building with blocks, making sure each part fits perfectly so the song flows smoothly when you sing it.

slides.text: When you PERFORM your song, remember everything you learned about presentations: stand confidently, look at your audience, project your voice, and COMMIT to the performance. It is okay if your voice is not perfect — what matters is that you EXPRESS something real through your song. The audience wants to FEEL what you feel. Sing with your whole heart!
slides.mascot_explanation: When you stand up to sing, you'll want to stand tall and proud, look at your friends, and sing with your whole voice! It's not about being perfect, it's about sharing how your song makes you feel and letting that feeling shine through.

slides.prompt:
Complete and rehearse your song:
1. Write your second verse (4 lines, same melody as verse 1, new content)
2. Practice your full song: Verse 1 → Chorus → Verse 2 → Chorus
3. Add dynamics: mark which parts are louder (f) and softer (p) on your lyric sheet
4. Practice with expression and feeling
5. Perform for your small group (2-3 classmates)
6. Get feedback: What feeling did the song give the audience?
Optional: Add simple percussion accompaniment (clapping, tapping, or instruments)
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's where all the magic happens! You'll write those new verse words, practice singing your whole song, decide where to sing louder or softer, and then sing it with all the feeling you can! After that, you'll sing for a few friends and they'll tell you what they liked best.

slides.text: You are songwriters AND performers! You took an idea, organized it into verses and a chorus, set it to melody, added expression, and performed it for an audience. That is exactly what professional musicians do. Whether or not you become musicians, the skills you practiced today — creativity, structure, expression, and courage — will serve you in everything you do.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a second verse that fits the melody? Do they understand verse-chorus structure? Can they vary dynamics and expression in their singing? Can they perform their complete song for an audience? Can they give feedback about the feeling a song creates?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You took your song from just an idea to a complete performance, just like real musicians do. You learned how to build a song, add exciting sounds, and share your voice with courage – those are super important skills for anything you do!

parent_notes: Songwriting workshop Part 2 builds on creativity with performance confidence. If your child is shy about singing, that is completely normal — encourage them gently but do not force. Some children prefer to speak their lyrics rhythmically rather than sing, and that is perfectly acceptable. The revision process (changing words to fit the melody) teaches that creativity involves editing, not just initial inspiration. If your child enjoyed this activity, encourage continued songwriting at home. You do not need musical training to support this — listening appreciatively and asking questions ('What is your song about? How does it make you feel?') is enough. Consider recording their song as a keepsake. The optional percussion accompaniment adds another layer of musical engagement.

title: Healthy Habits — Emotional Wellness and Stress Management
description: Students explore emotional health as a component of overall wellness. They learn to identify and name their emotions, understand that all feelings are normal, and practice healthy coping strategies for stress, frustration, and anxiety. They create a personal 'calm down toolkit.'
instructions:
1. Connect to previous health lessons: body health AND mind health matter equally.
2. What are emotions? Natural responses to what happens around us and inside us.
3. Naming emotions: expand vocabulary beyond happy/sad/mad — use a feelings chart.
4. All feelings are normal — there are no 'bad' emotions, only helpful and unhelpful RESPONSES.
5. What is stress? The body's response to challenges. Some stress helps; too much hurts.
6. Signs of stress: stomachache, headache, trouble sleeping, irritability, trouble focusing.
7. Healthy coping strategies: deep breathing, exercise, talking to someone, journaling, nature.
8. Deep breathing practice: 4 counts in, hold 4, out 4 (box breathing).
9. Students create a personal 'Calm Down Toolkit' — 5 strategies they will try.
10. Role-play: practice using a coping strategy in a stressful scenario.

slides.heading: Emotional Wellness
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our lesson! It tells us we're going to learn about "Emotional Wellness," which is all about understanding how we feel inside and how to take care of those feelings. It's like learning how to be a good friend to yourself!

items: Feelings chart with diverse emotion words
Optional: stress ball or fidget tool for demonstration
slides.setup_instructions: Create or print a feelings chart with at least 20 emotion words organized by category (happy family: joyful, excited, grateful, proud; sad family: disappointed, lonely, homesick; angry family: frustrated, annoyed, furious; scared family: nervous, worried, anxious). Prepare a Calm Down Toolkit template with space for 5 strategies and illustrations. Create a calm, comfortable atmosphere for this sensitive topic.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at all these things! We have a chart with lots of feeling words, like a special dictionary for emotions, and a blank card called a "Calm Down Toolkit" template where we'll write our own ideas. We also have colored pencils to make our toolkits colorful and fun, and a journal for writing our thoughts. If you see a squishy ball, that's just an example of something to help you feel calm!

slides.text: We have been learning about keeping our BODIES healthy with good food, sleep, and exercise. But health includes our MINDS and FEELINGS too. EMOTIONAL WELLNESS means understanding your feelings, knowing that ALL feelings are normal, and having healthy ways to handle difficult emotions. Just like you brush your teeth to keep them healthy, you need tools to keep your emotional health strong.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is telling us that just like we take care of our bodies by eating yummy fruits and sleeping, we also need to take care of our minds and feelings. Being emotionally well means knowing what you're feeling and having good ways to handle tough feelings, kind of like having special tools to keep your mind strong and happy.

slides.text: Let us expand our feelings vocabulary. Most people say they feel 'happy,' 'sad,' or 'mad' — but there are SO many more feelings! You might feel PROUD when you finish something difficult, FRUSTRATED when you cannot figure something out, ANXIOUS when something new is coming, GRATEFUL when someone is kind, or LONELY when you miss a friend. The more precisely you can NAME your feeling, the better you can understand and manage it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to learn that there are way more feelings than just happy, sad, or mad! Think about feeling super proud when you learn something new, or maybe a little worried before trying something different. The more words we have for our feelings, the easier it is to understand what's going on inside us.

slides.text: Here is an important truth: there are NO bad feelings. Anger is not bad — it tells you something is unfair. Fear is not bad — it keeps you safe. Sadness is not bad — it shows you care. The feelings themselves are normal and natural. What matters is what you DO with them. Punching a wall when angry is an unhelpful response. Taking deep breaths and talking about why you are angry is a helpful response.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important idea: no feeling is a "bad" feeling! Even when you feel angry or sad, those feelings are normal and tell you something important. What really matters is what you *do* when you feel that way; for example, it's better to take deep breaths than to stomp your feet really hard.

slides.text: When you feel stressed or overwhelmed, your body goes into 'fight or flight' mode — your heart beats faster, your muscles tighten, your breathing gets shallow. You can REVERSE this with calming strategies. Let us practice BOX BREATHING: breathe IN for 4 counts, HOLD for 4 counts, breathe OUT for 4 counts, HOLD for 4 counts. Repeat 4 times. Feel how your body calms down? This works EVERY time because it tells your brain that you are safe.
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes, when things feel tricky or overwhelming, our bodies get a little stressed out, kind of like a car engine running too fast. This slide shows us a special trick called "box breathing" to help calm our bodies down. We breathe in for four seconds, hold for four, breathe out for four, and hold again for four – it's like a little reset button for your body!

slides.prompt:
Create your personal Calm Down Toolkit:
1. Practice box breathing together (4 rounds)
2. Choose 5 coping strategies that work for YOU from this list: deep breathing, going for a walk, drawing, listening to music, talking to someone you trust, squeezing a stress ball, writing in a journal, counting to 10, doing yoga poses, spending time in nature
3. Write each strategy on your toolkit card and draw an illustration
4. Role-play: Your partner describes a stressful situation, you choose a strategy from your toolkit and practice using it
5. In your journal, write about a time you felt stressed and what helped (or what you wish you had done)
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the fun activity part where you get to make your very own "Calm Down Toolkit"! First, we'll practice that box breathing together. Then, you'll pick five things that help *you* feel calm, like drawing or talking to someone, and draw a picture for each one on your toolkit card. It's like creating your own secret superhero power-up kit for tough feelings!
